componenttext: Greetings, and welcome to the CBRE fourth quarter earnings call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to your host, Steve Iaco, with Investor Relations. Thank you. You may now begin.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome to CBRE's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Earlier today, we issued a press release announcing our financial results for the quarter and full year. This release is posted on the homepage of our website, cbre.com. This c
componenttext:
Thank you, and welcome to CBRE's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Earlier today, we issued a press release announcing our financial results for the quarter and full year. This release is posted on the homepage of our website, cbre.com. This conference call is being webcast through the Investor Relations section of our website. You can also find there a presentation slide deck, which you can use to follow along with our prepared remarks. An audio archive of the webcast will be posted to the website later today, and a transcript of our call will be posted tomorrow.
Now please turn to the slide labeled Forward-Looking Statements. This presentation contains statements that are forward-looking within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These include statements regarding CBRE's future growth momentum, operations, business outlook, financial performance, market share, earnings and adjusted EPS expectations for 2016. These statements should be considered to be estimates only, and actual results may ultimately differ from these estimates. Except to the extent required by securities laws, we undertake no obligation to update or publicly revise any forward-looking statements we may make today.
For a full discussion of the risks and other factors that may impact any forward-looking statements, please refer to our fourth quarter earnings report filed on Form 8-K, our quarterly report on Form 10-Q for the quarter ended September 30, 2015, and our most recent annual report on Form 10-K. These reports are filed with the SEC and available at sec.gov.
During this presentation, we may make certain statements that refer to non-GAAP financial measures as defined by SEC regulations. Where required by these regulations, we have provided reconciliations of these measures to what we believe are the most directly comparable GAAP measures. These reconciliations, together with explanations of these measures, can be found within the Appendix of this presentation.
Please turn to Slide 3. Participating on our call today are Bob Sulentic, our President and Chief Executive Officer; Jim Groch, our Chief Financial Officer; and Gil Borok, our Deputy Chief Financial Officer and Chief Accounting Officer.
Please turn to Slide 4 as I turn the call over to Bob.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve, and good morning, everyone. 2015 was another year of exceptional performance for CBRE, and this strong performance continued through the fourth quarter. For both periods, we set new company records for revenue and adjusted earnings and d
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve, and good morning, everyone. 2015 was another year of exceptional performance for CBRE, and this strong performance continued through the fourth quarter. For both periods, we set new company records for revenue and adjusted earnings and drove double-digit growth. We're the first firm in our sector to exceed $10 billion in revenue and $1.4 billion in normalized EBITDA, and we attained these milestones while making strategic gains across CBRE.
Notably, our occupier outsourcing business is materially stronger with the acquisition of the Global Workplace Solutions business. We have an unrivaled ability to self-performed facilities management services around the world. In capital markets, we made market share gains around the globe. We acquired 9 leading companies in 2015, enhancing our capabilities in energy management, retail data analytics, capital markets and consulting.
We had our third straight year of outsized recruiting gains as hundreds of new senior brokerage and capital markets professionals, net of departures, elected to join our team. The average production of people joining our team is 3x higher than those who leave. We opened our 30th new state-of-the-art, alternative workplace office, providing our people with a collaborative and innovative work environment.
Finally, we ended the year with a balance sheet that is stronger than at any time in recent history, highlighted by investment grade credit ratings. We thank our more than 70,000 employees for an excellent year in 2015 and for their commitment to our clients. 
Now Jim will take you through our results in greater detail.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bob. Please turn to Slide 5. As you've seen in our press release, CBRE's growth in 2015 was outstanding: revenue rose 20% to $10.9 billion; fee revenue increased 14% to $7.7 billion; normalized EBITDA rose 21% to $1.4 billion; and adjusted EPS
componenttext:
Thank you, Bob. Please turn to Slide 5. As you've seen in our press release, CBRE's growth in 2015 was outstanding: revenue rose 20% to $10.9 billion; fee revenue increased 14% to $7.7 billion; normalized EBITDA rose 21% to $1.4 billion; and adjusted EPS was up 22% to $2.05 this year. Profitability was strong with an 18.3% normalized EBITDA margin on fee revenue in 2015, up approximately 110 basis points from 2014. This performance was achieved in spite of significant headwinds from currency movements. 
Our 3 regional service segments achieved a 27% increase in normalized EBITDA with a margin on fee revenue of 16.5%, up 100 basis points for the year. 
Bob mentioned the strength of our balance sheet. Despite investing approximately $1.6 billion in 9 acquisitions during the year, we ended 2015 with no outstanding borrowings on our $2.6 billion revolving credit facility, $470 million of available cash in short-term investments and net debt of just under 1.6x normalized EBITDA.
Please turn to Slide 6 for a look at full year revenue growth by line of business. Our businesses continued to exhibit excellent broad-based momentum in 2015. Revenue from contractual sources totaled $6 billion. Contractual fee revenue was $2.9 billion, up 29% in local currency or 14% without the contributions from the acquired Global Workplace Solutions business. Leasing surpassed $2.5 billion of global revenue, up 11% in local currency.
The Capital markets business, property sales and mortgage services exceeded $2.1 billion in revenue and achieved 20% growth in local currency. The multiyear shift towards a more stable recurring business mix continued in 2015. Contractual fee revenue plus leasing, which is largely recurring, totaled 70%.
Please turn to Slide 7, where we will shift our attention from the full year to a review of our financial performance in Q4. 
Revenue and adjusted earnings growth for the quarter was very strong. Fee revenue improved 23% in local currency and 10% without the contribution from the acquired Global Workplace Solutions business. This growth was achieved on top of an exceptionally strong Q4 2014 when revenue increased 28% versus Q4 2013.
Normalized EBITDA for the quarter totaled $518 million, a 26% increase from last year's Q4, with 31% increase in local currency. Our profit margin also improved significantly. At 20.3%, our normalized EBITDA margin on fee revenue increased 130 basis points over prior year Q4. Adjusted earnings per share increased 19% to $0.81 for the quarter.  
Q4 2015 normalized EBITDA reflects the following adjustments: $26 million of carried interest expense, which we will recognize in future periods when we record associated revenue. This aligns with timing of expense and revenue recognition; $24 million of integration costs related to the acquisition of Global Workplace Solutions; and $40 million incurred to eliminate costs to enhance margins going forward. 
Please turn to Slide 8, where we will review Q4 results for our 3 regional services segments, all in local currency. Fee revenue increased 17% in the Americas as every business line exhibited growth. In EMEA, fee revenue improved 36% as we saw healthy gains across the region, particularly in Germany, the Netherlands, Spain, Switzerland and the United Kingdom. In Asia Pacific, fee revenue rose 27%, with Australia, Greater China and India setting the pace for growth.
Absent the contributions from the acquired Global Workplace Solutions business, fee revenue rose 9% in the Americas, 12% in EMEA and 11% in Asia Pacific. Normalized EBITDA increased 9% for the Americas, 45% for EMEA and 24% for Asia Pacific. Q4 normalized EBITDA margin on fee revenue for the 3 regions combined was 16.3%.
Please turn to Slide 9 for a review of the performance of our major global lines of business in Q4. All percentage increases are in local currency. For the company as a whole, contractual fee revenue plus leasing, which is largely recurring, totaled 73% of fee revenue for the quarter. Occupier outsourcing fee revenue more than doubled with the acquisition of Global Workplace Solutions.
Excluding contributions from this acquisition, occupier outsourcing continued to exhibit strong double-digit growth with a 19% increase in fee revenue. Asset Services had a strong quarter. Fee revenues increased 12% with notable growth in EMEA and the Americas. Investment Management also had a strong quarter. Revenue rose 22%, driven by carried interest on property dispositions, reflecting strong returns generated for fund investors.
Our Evaluations business grew revenue 9%. Leasing revenue rose 8% growth in the United States, which reflects a solid performance on top of an exceptionally strong 28% year-over-year increase in the fourth quarter of 2014. Global growth and leasing was paced by a 22% increase in Europe, notably France and the United Kingdom, as well as strong contributions from Canada and Mexico.
Our capital markets business remained highly active globally, although growth rates slowed from earlier in the year. Global property sales rose 7% after accounting for a decline in market volumes from the United Kingdom. The global growth rate in Q4, excluding the United Kingdom was 13%. Investor interest in the United Kingdom remained strong, with cap rates stable and rental rates increasing in Q4, but we are seeing capital migrate to Continental Europe as local economies there strengthen and property yields are higher.
In the United States, our sales revenues grew 10% as we once again gained significant market share according to RCA. Commercial mortgage services revenue increased 6%. As expected, gains from mortgage servicing rights with the U.S. government-sponsored enterprises were flat as the agencies reached the regulatory caps on their lending.
However, loan originations were higher with banks, conduits and other debt capital sources. Our global loan servicing portfolio totaled $135 billion at year-end.
Please turn to Slide 10 regarding our occupier outsourcing business, which is reported within the 3 regional services segments. Even without the benefit of the acquired Global Workplace Solutions business, 2015 was a record year in terms of occupier outsourcing contracts. We brought on board more new clients and importantly expanded our service scope for more existing clients than ever before. In addition, we continue to make meaningful inroads in Europe and Asia as well as in key verticals like healthcare, data centers and life sciences.
Feedback from our clients has exceeded our expectations, and we are on course to materially complete client facing integration activities over the next 60 days.
Please turn to Slide 11 regarding our Global Investment Management segment. Revenue rose 22% in local currency and normalized EBITDA nearly doubled, fueled by $30 million of carried interest tied to significant returns for our clients on property dispositions. The strong performance of our investment programs relative to industry benchmarks continues to help us attract capital. New equity commitments totaled $7 billion in 2015. 
In Q4, Assets Under Management grew by $3 billion to $89 billion after a $1.1 billion drag from currency movement. For the year, AUM was up $1.9 billion in local currency, but down $1.6 billion when converted into U.S. dollars.
Please turn to Slide 12 regarding our Development Services segment. As anticipated, Development Services had a very strong quarter. Several large asset sales resulted in EBITDA of nearly $75 million for Q4. Development projects in-process totaled $6.7 billion at year-end 2015, up $1.3 billion from 2014. The pipeline inventory totaled $3.6 billion, down $0.4 billion as projects converted to in-process. 
Please turn to Slide 13. I will conclude my remarks by reiterating 3 points that highlight the financial strength of the business. Normalized EBITDA was up 21% for the year and 26% for the quarter. We achieved a margin on fee revenue of 18.3% for the year, and our available liquidity exceeds $3 billion. 
Now please turn to Slide 14 as I turn the call back to Bob for closing remarks.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. From all you've heard today, it should be clear that CBRE has a sustainable competitive advantage. Our leading global brand and strong culture help us to attract and keep tremendous talent in highly desirable clients. Investments in our platf
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim. From all you've heard today, it should be clear that CBRE has a sustainable competitive advantage. Our leading global brand and strong culture help us to attract and keep tremendous talent in highly desirable clients. Investments in our platform, especially in technology and data analytics, are helping our people to create more value for these clients. Our revenue base is more stable and stickier than ever before.
For 2016, we expect occupier outsourcing to continue its track record of strong performance. We anticipate low double-digit revenue growth this year before the contributions from the acquired Global Workplace Solutions business. Leasing revenue should increase at a high single-digit rate as we continue to gain market share. Our capital markets businesses, which consist of property sales and mortgage services, are most influenced by the financial markets, and volumes can be hard to predict quarter-to-quarter. 
However, we believe that the strong fundamentals and the value that real estate offers relative to other asset classes will continue to draw global capital to real estate in 2016. We estimate our capital markets revenue will grow to rate in the mid- to high single digits. Normalized EBITDA from our combined principal businesses, Global Investment Management and Development Services is anticipated to be flat to slightly down in 2016, reflecting a very strong 2015.
The shift to a more stable recurring business mix will continue as our financial results include a full year contribution from the acquired Global Workplace Solutions business. Even with this shift in business mix, in 2016, we expect our industry-leading margin on fee revenue to approximate 17%. While we are mindful of concerns about China's slowing growth and the effect of lower oil prices, fundamentals in our sector remain on solid footing. We're positioned for another strong year in 2016, but are maintaining flexibility in case the economy weakens.
Our outlook is based on economists consensus view that the global economy will maintain its modest rate of growth in 2016. We anticipate double-digit growth again this year supported by continued gains in market share and expect to achieve adjusted earnings per share in the range of $2.27 to $2.37 for 2016. This equates to a growth rate of 13% at the midpoint of our guidance.
With that, operator, we'll open the lines for questions.

componenttext: Okay. And then just as of now and just to think about your outlook, you mentioned using your guidepost as economists' views. Just curious like, if anything's changed since your Business Review Day in November in terms of how you're seeing clients behave or seeing demand, either regionally or by business segment, if that's decelerated, stayed about the same or just how you're feeling about that outside of perhaps maybe what the economists are calling for?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes -- no, outside of what the economists are talking about, what we're seeing with our clients is what you see in the guidance we gave by line of business. It's an active marketplace for what we do. We're a month into the year, and its the slowest month
componenttext: Yes -- no, outside of what the economists are talking about, what we're seeing with our clients is what you see in the guidance we gave by line of business. It's an active marketplace for what we do. We're a month into the year, and its the slowest month of the year, so you can't draw any conclusions. We've reflected what we believe kind of the collective view of our people and our people on The Street so to speak and our research people and our economists think and that's all wound up in the guidance we gave by line of business.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brad Burke with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brad Burke with Goldman Sachs.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you'd maybe spend more time just talking about the durability of your business as it stands currently in the event of an economic downturn, considering what we're all seeing in public equity markets and headlines over the last few months. May
componenttext: I was hoping you'd maybe spend more time just talking about the durability of your business as it stands currently in the event of an economic downturn, considering what we're all seeing in public equity markets and headlines over the last few months. Maybe you can give us some metrics to think about on how your business would perform if we were to have a recession and how that compares with what we saw during the last recession?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as you know, I think the business is a dramatically different business than existed back in say, 2006 or '07 before the last recession. Capital markets, which is the piece with more variability, it's more economically sensitive, it's a much smaller
componenttext: Well, as you know, I think the business is a dramatically different business than existed back in say, 2006 or '07 before the last recession. Capital markets, which is the piece with more variability, it's more economically sensitive, it's a much smaller part of the overall business; the contractual revenues, in particular, asset management and facility management, generally are either stable; or in the case of Asset Services, countercyclical, make up a much, much larger percentage of the business. And that's growing and will continue to grow as the results -- as the acquisition shows up in our full year numbers. So I think the business is just a different business than existed at that time. The other comment I would make is our balance sheet is a dramatically different balance sheet than existed at that time because we have enormous liquidity. We have very, very few -- very, very small amounts of maturities coming out for the next several years. So we are, I think, nicely poised to take advantage of opportunities. There are parts of our business that will be impacted if we have -- if we go into a recession, but overall, I think, we'll see tremendous opportunities to take advantage of as well.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And maybe talking about the opportunities, since M&A has been such a focus, can you talk about the flexibility you're looking to maintain? Does that imply potential slowdown in incremental M&A activity? And also when you look at M&A targets, are you seein
componenttext: And maybe talking about the opportunities, since M&A has been such a focus, can you talk about the flexibility you're looking to maintain? Does that imply potential slowdown in incremental M&A activity? And also when you look at M&A targets, are you seeing any of the weakness that we're seeing in the public equity markets begin to be reflected in the private M&A multiples that you would be looking at?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brad, this is Bob. When we talk about the opportunities we're going to see in a downturn and how we're positioned relative to the last cycle, as Jim said, not only is our balance sheet dramatically more compelling, we've made a lot of investments in
componenttext: Yes, Brad, this is Bob. When we talk about the opportunities we're going to see in a downturn and how we're positioned relative to the last cycle, as Jim said, not only is our balance sheet dramatically more compelling, we've made a lot of investments in our business that make this a better place for people to come to. Infill acquisitions want to be here more, brokers want to be here more, because of the way we can support them through the capabilities we have. And as a result, we think in a downturn, not only will we have the financial dry powder to invest, we'll have a platform that will be more attractive to different types of targets, people and businesses. And that proposition we think is really exciting for our company.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just the thoughts on incremental M&A at this point, would -- for fill-in acquisitions, would we expect you to continue the pace that we've seen over the course of 2015?
componenttext: Okay. And just the thoughts on incremental M&A at this point, would -- for fill-in acquisitions, would we expect you to continue the pace that we've seen over the course of 2015?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we're just going to have to see how that plays out. We continue to be very disciplined. We do still have a nice, strong volume of infill M&A, as strong as we've seen in the past. But we are selective around fit, and we're very careful around prici
componenttext: I think we're just going to have to see how that plays out. We continue to be very disciplined. We do still have a nice, strong volume of infill M&A, as strong as we've seen in the past. But we are selective around fit, and we're very careful around pricing.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And somewhat related to that, are you able to say with the balance sheet being at 1.6x EBITDA now, what the guidance range that you've given today would imply for year-end 2016 leverage levels?
componenttext: Okay. And somewhat related to that, are you able to say with the balance sheet being at 1.6x EBITDA now, what the guidance range that you've given today would imply for year-end 2016 leverage levels?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're not going to give a specific number on that, but you know the amount of cash flow that we're generating, so that -- unless we do a large transaction in the year, it's likely that we'll end the year at a lower leverage rate.
componenttext: We're not going to give a specific number on that, but you know the amount of cash flow that we're generating, so that -- unless we do a large transaction in the year, it's likely that we'll end the year at a lower leverage rate.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Ridley-Lane with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Ridley-Lane with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So there've been some surveys about tightening underwriting standards on commercial real estate loans and some new risk retention regulations come in, in effect, later this year that may reduce CMBS. I'm just wondering are you seeing sort of similar trend
componenttext: So there've been some surveys about tightening underwriting standards on commercial real estate loans and some new risk retention regulations come in, in effect, later this year that may reduce CMBS. I'm just wondering are you seeing sort of similar trends in your commercial debt markets and what would you expect the impact to be on the capital markets business in 2016 from that.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say -- I guess I'd start by saying the impact from anything that we're aware of is baked into our guidance. And I'd also comment that we believe real estate offers compelling value today relative to other asset classes, and capital flows into real est
componenttext: I'd say -- I guess I'd start by saying the impact from anything that we're aware of is baked into our guidance. And I'd also comment that we believe real estate offers compelling value today relative to other asset classes, and capital flows into real estate from enormously varied range of investment types and vehicles. And just the strength of the fundamentals in the sector and the value that's embedded in that asset class and what we've seen in the market and the performance in Q4 leaves us feeling fairly optimistic about the strength of the sector.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And then I'm a little bit surprised on the commentary that the 2 principal businesses could be flat in terms of the EBITDA contribution in '16. Are there specific funds that are coming to maturity? Or any development projects that are nearing sales
componenttext: Sure. And then I'm a little bit surprised on the commentary that the 2 principal businesses could be flat in terms of the EBITDA contribution in '16. Are there specific funds that are coming to maturity? Or any development projects that are nearing sales that give you a pretty good visibility and confidence in that projection?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, we do have good visibility into those businesses, and the reason we're projecting flat to slightly down is because we had a particularly good fourth quarter this year. And so we could be surprised, as we were this year, by the time we get to next y
componenttext: David, we do have good visibility into those businesses, and the reason we're projecting flat to slightly down is because we had a particularly good fourth quarter this year. And so we could be surprised, as we were this year, by the time we get to next year. But we have -- in both of those businesses, we have things going on that make us think we'll do similarly to what we did this year, which would be good performance.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And the last one from me, the publicly traded REIT indexes have moved down. I'm wondering if you've seen a widening out in the private market for bid-ask spreads in the capital markets business most recently here in January.
componenttext: Got it. And the last one from me, the publicly traded REIT indexes have moved down. I'm wondering if you've seen a widening out in the private market for bid-ask spreads in the capital markets business most recently here in January.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: What I would say on that, the best data probably is just the cap rates where deals were closing. And cap rates have either been flat or improved a bit, i.e., cap rates if you're a seller cap rates have come down. So we're not seeing that.
componenttext: What I would say on that, the best data probably is just the cap rates where deals were closing. And cap rates have either been flat or improved a bit, i.e., cap rates if you're a seller cap rates have come down. So we're not seeing that.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brandon Dobell with William Blair.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brandon Dobell with William Blair.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe a little color on how -- I guess how closely tied the leasing business is becoming to the occupier outsourcing and Asset Services maybe from a couple of points of view. One, how much of leasing revenues in '15 had some connection either tight or loo
componenttext: Maybe a little color on how -- I guess how closely tied the leasing business is becoming to the occupier outsourcing and Asset Services maybe from a couple of points of view. One, how much of leasing revenues in '15 had some connection either tight or loose some of the occupier and asset contracts? How should we think about that number progressing in '16? And from a contribution point of view, given your comments on how leasing growth should look in '16, how much variability around that growth rate could come from what happens with the occupier outsourcing and Asset Services connections with leasing?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brandon, this is Jim. I think our strength in the occupier outsourcing business supports our ability to gain market share in the occupier leasing side of the business, and that's really the impact. As we expand contractual relationships with clients on an
componenttext: Brandon, this is Jim. I think our strength in the occupier outsourcing business supports our ability to gain market share in the occupier leasing side of the business, and that's really the impact. As we expand contractual relationships with clients on an multiproduct outsourcing basis, that business becomes stickier, actually, contractual in many cases. And you see our market share improving, and it's just one of the factors that supports our market share gains in the leasing business.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Any sense of how head count growth looked '15 versus '14, in leasing in particular, but also across capital markets?
componenttext: Any sense of how head count growth looked '15 versus '14, in leasing in particular, but also across capital markets?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brandon, we had -- we won't be giving specific numbers. But we had a third straight year of very, very strong gains associated with recruiting in both the capital markets side and the -- as we call it the brokerage side or the leasing side to the tun
componenttext: Yes, Brandon, we had -- we won't be giving specific numbers. But we had a third straight year of very, very strong gains associated with recruiting in both the capital markets side and the -- as we call it the brokerage side or the leasing side to the tune of hundreds of brokers net. The other thing that's really important there is that the average production and we do track this quite closely, the average production of the people we're bringing on is 3x the average production of the brokers that are exiting. And sometimes you'll read in the marketplace or hear a story about a CBRE broker that landed somewhere else. We have close tabs on those ins and outs, and not only is the headcount up pretty materially, but the average production per producer coming in is very strong.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then either for Jim or Gil, you've talked about the cost containment expenses. I think it was a $40 million number in the quarter. What is that? Should we expect it to keep going? Is that related to GWS? Or is it just something separate? Just wa
componenttext: Okay. And then either for Jim or Gil, you've talked about the cost containment expenses. I think it was a $40 million number in the quarter. What is that? Should we expect it to keep going? Is that related to GWS? Or is it just something separate? Just want to get a better sense of what that is and how we should think about it this year?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Late in the second half of last year, we started looking around at our businesses. We had almost doubled the size of the company in 4 years. And as we get more granular, looking at the margins in the company and businesses around the world, we've st
componenttext: Sure. Late in the second half of last year, we started looking around at our businesses. We had almost doubled the size of the company in 4 years. And as we get more granular, looking at the margins in the company and businesses around the world, we've started to focus more on businesses that have margins that we felt should be higher than they were. And that's been our focus, and that's what those charges are. So they're -- while we grew headcount quite a bit in the business, we did have material number of folks that we let go to make businesses more efficient where we just felt the business were underperforming. And we'll probably -- we'll be continuing to look for those opportunities throughout the year.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess was that or will it be concentrated in a particular geography or service line?
componenttext: I guess was that or will it be concentrated in a particular geography or service line?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we're looking everywhere. As you know, we get pretty granular down in the market and the sub markets around the world by lines of business. So its a global initiative to be particularly focused on businesses that just may not have received as much att
componenttext: No, we're looking everywhere. As you know, we get pretty granular down in the market and the sub markets around the world by lines of business. So its a global initiative to be particularly focused on businesses that just may not have received as much attention as perhaps they should've received at the time where we've just been growing the business so much.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then final one from me. Your expectations for, I guess, synergies or growth from GWS compared to the prior expectations you guys had put out around the time of the acquisition, how do we think about that contribution or impact in '16 versus
componenttext: All right. And then final one from me. Your expectations for, I guess, synergies or growth from GWS compared to the prior expectations you guys had put out around the time of the acquisition, how do we think about that contribution or impact in '16 versus your prior thoughts?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No change to our prior guidance. I think we're very much on track with the guidance we've given.
componenttext: No change to our prior guidance. I think we're very much on track with the guidance we've given.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Mitch Germain with JMP Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mitch Germain with JMP Securities.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, you talked about the addition of several hundred net producers. I guess I'm just curious I couldn't understand from your commentary in terms of your sentiment toward recruiting going into 2016. Is it just as strong? Or has it come down a bit here?
componenttext: Bob, you talked about the addition of several hundred net producers. I guess I'm just curious I couldn't understand from your commentary in terms of your sentiment toward recruiting going into 2016. Is it just as strong? Or has it come down a bit here?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Here's how we think about that. Every year, we have targets, Mitch, and we have a very active program with our leaders around the world. And when I say leaders around the world, not just at the high level, but all the way into the local markets to recruit
componenttext: Here's how we think about that. Every year, we have targets, Mitch, and we have a very active program with our leaders around the world. And when I say leaders around the world, not just at the high level, but all the way into the local markets to recruit. We will have that again this year. The last 3 years, we've exceeded our going in expectations. We will pursue an aggressive path this year, and as the year unfolds, we'll determine what we actually do. One of the things I will say is that there's been some foolish deals made in all 3 regions of the world in recruiting. We will not participate in that activity. We'll be very careful on a individual-by-individual basis to make sure everybody we bring on, on a basis works obviously for them but also for our company. And we'll see how the marketplace for recruiting unfolds during the year. But going in, we expect to have an aggressive program, again, this year.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just with your thoughts regarding capital markets, your guidance kind of mid- to high single digit. Is there a way to kind of think about how you're looking at that on a regional basis?
componenttext: Great. And then just with your thoughts regarding capital markets, your guidance kind of mid- to high single digit. Is there a way to kind of think about how you're looking at that on a regional basis?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the only comment we make on a regional basis is that we expect Asia Pacific region to be softer, although, let's say, in the range of plus or minus flat relative to the Americas and Europe, where we expect it to be stronger.
componenttext: I think the only comment we make on a regional basis is that we expect Asia Pacific region to be softer, although, let's say, in the range of plus or minus flat relative to the Americas and Europe, where we expect it to be stronger.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Last one from me. Just curious...
componenttext: Great. Last one from me. Just curious...

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The other comment I would make is just Asia is obviously a pretty small part of our business in the capital markets side.
componenttext: The other comment I would make is just Asia is obviously a pretty small part of our business in the capital markets side.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. Understood. How's the integration going at this point? I know you updated us at the Investor Day, but just curious as we sit in here in the start of February.
componenttext: Understood. Understood. How's the integration going at this point? I know you updated us at the Investor Day, but just curious as we sit in here in the start of February.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The big thing I'd point to there, Mitch, is our people and our clients, it's going quite well with our clients. And the single-most probably satisfying part of this whole combination is that our people and the legacy GWS people are really quite excited ab
componenttext: The big thing I'd point to there, Mitch, is our people and our clients, it's going quite well with our clients. And the single-most probably satisfying part of this whole combination is that our people and the legacy GWS people are really quite excited about what the combined business has to offer. So it's going well with our clients, it's going well with our people and Jim already commented on the financial side of things as expected.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: How does the cross-sell of services -- I mean what's the timing on when you could start to unlock some of those ancillary revenues?
componenttext: How does the cross-sell of services -- I mean what's the timing on when you could start to unlock some of those ancillary revenues?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our position on that hasn't changed. It hasn't been even 6 months yet. And so our total focus is on transitioning those accounts, transitioning the people related to the accounts and doing a great job for the clients. And if we do that, we're going to hav
componenttext: Our position on that hasn't changed. It hasn't been even 6 months yet. And so our total focus is on transitioning those accounts, transitioning the people related to the accounts and doing a great job for the clients. And if we do that, we're going to have lots of cross-sell opportunities because those are big, big names, obviously, in the corporate world, and they have a lot of real estate needs. And we think there will be opportunity out there, but we're not handicapping what that will be. We're simply focused on doing a great job for them under the assumption that, that will be rewarded when it happens.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Anthony Paolone JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Anthony Paolone JPMorgan.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a few follow-ups. Can you put any parameters around investment sales? And how much of that revenue comes from, say, smaller building sales, whatever that breakpoint may be in your view versus, say, the more core major assets in the more institutional
componenttext: Just a few follow-ups. Can you put any parameters around investment sales? And how much of that revenue comes from, say, smaller building sales, whatever that breakpoint may be in your view versus, say, the more core major assets in the more institutional realm? Just trying to understand where the revenue comes from there?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Anthony, we don't break that out. We do have substantial businesses at all -- both ends of the spectrum and in the middle. And by the way, both ends and the middle are all growing, but we do not break that out.
componenttext: Anthony, we don't break that out. We do have substantial businesses at all -- both ends of the spectrum and in the middle. And by the way, both ends and the middle are all growing, but we do not break that out.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so I guess, going down the path in my mind, thinking about CMBS spreads widening and the liquidity there getting more difficult, do you see that putting pressure on perhaps the lower end of that spectrum at all? Or is that not something you guys belie
componenttext: And so I guess, going down the path in my mind, thinking about CMBS spreads widening and the liquidity there getting more difficult, do you see that putting pressure on perhaps the lower end of that spectrum at all? Or is that not something you guys believe is going to play out?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't see that having a big impact. There are just -- there are enough varied sources of capital and enough interest in the sector that we don't think that will have a big impact.
componenttext: We don't see that having a big impact. There are just -- there are enough varied sources of capital and enough interest in the sector that we don't think that will have a big impact.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in Europe, it seems like there's been this divergence between what's happened on the sales side and the leasing side. How do you think that plays out in the next few quarters?
componenttext: Okay. And then in Europe, it seems like there's been this divergence between what's happened on the sales side and the leasing side. How do you think that plays out in the next few quarters?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean it's a little hard to say because it's also varied from market to market. So the U.K., on the sales side has been incredibly strong, for a number of years, volume was down significantly in the quarter and yet cap rates were lower, i.e., impro
componenttext: Well, I mean it's a little hard to say because it's also varied from market to market. So the U.K., on the sales side has been incredibly strong, for a number of years, volume was down significantly in the quarter and yet cap rates were lower, i.e., improved if you're a seller in the quarter and rental rates rose in Q4 in the U.K. from Q3. So the fundamentals of the market are really strong, and I think, capital tends to get ahead of the fundamentals. So investors are smart, and they're looking ahead. And I think we're now finally seeing the fundamentals begin to improve in a material way on the leasing side, but that's -- that in and of itself is positive for the capital side as well. So I think it's playing out in a way that feels rational, and I can -- couldn't comment more than that.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then with regards to the more onetime in nature items like the business initiatives and the deal-related cost, I know those are tough to predict, but you had a lot of them in the quarter. Does that come down in the next few quarters? Or do you e
componenttext: Okay. And then with regards to the more onetime in nature items like the business initiatives and the deal-related cost, I know those are tough to predict, but you had a lot of them in the quarter. Does that come down in the next few quarters? Or do you expect an elevated level of those types of adjustments because of some of the reviews of the businesses that you mentioned earlier?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're not predicting any specific numbers on that front. I will tell you that we're very careful about numbers that we normalize. So we're always cutting -- we're always attentive to cost structure, and we're always trimming a little here or there and we
componenttext: We're not predicting any specific numbers on that front. I will tell you that we're very careful about numbers that we normalize. So we're always cutting -- we're always attentive to cost structure, and we're always trimming a little here or there and we don't normalize for that activity. We don't even normalize for one-time costs on most of our infill acquisitions. So we try to be prudent around how we think about and deal with one-time costs. And even now, as we're going through what's a more material cost reduction program where it does make sense to  normalize out some of these costs, so people have a real understanding of the underlying business. Even in that process, we're being very careful, where we let someone go because of underperformance, to not count that cost or any costs that might be attributed to that because those aren't more permanent-type productions. So I think you can feel comfortable as an investor that we're attentive to trying to be thoughtful about that. And if you see more one-time costs, it'll be because we found opportunities to increase margins and businesses, and there's some real cost associated with it.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And as you guys go through this review and look at the cost structure, I know in the last downturn, I think -- I don't remember exactly what the number was, but it was -- I think well into the hundreds of millions of dollars that you guys pulled out
componenttext: Okay. And as you guys go through this review and look at the cost structure, I know in the last downturn, I think -- I don't remember exactly what the number was, but it was -- I think well into the hundreds of millions of dollars that you guys pulled out of the system. Do you think that there's things of that magnitude that are going to emerge? Or do you feel like you're going into '16 with just a much leaner business than perhaps in hindsight you had going into the last downturn?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Anthony, this is nothing remotely like that. The cost we cut in the fourth quarter and the program we're working with is, as Jim said, it's not the routine ongoing shedding of costs here and there in the business. It was a meaningful cost-cutting effort,
componenttext: Anthony, this is nothing remotely like that. The cost we cut in the fourth quarter and the program we're working with is, as Jim said, it's not the routine ongoing shedding of costs here and there in the business. It was a meaningful cost-cutting effort, but it is not in the same league with what we did in '07, '08 -- I guess '08 and '09. Nothing like that. The business is generally lean. But it's -- look, we've grown for several years, and as Jim said, we've doubled the business over the last 4 years and we've been focused on offense and we found there was some opportunity. So we got after it in a meaningful way. But it's not what you remember from before.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and Anthony, just to put that into perspective, I mean the cost cutting, the charge there is it's less than half of 1% of our cost structure. So the business is much, much larger, and the cost cuts are much, much smaller. I think we're really -- we'r
componenttext: Yes, and Anthony, just to put that into perspective, I mean the cost cutting, the charge there is it's less than half of 1% of our cost structure. So the business is much, much larger, and the cost cuts are much, much smaller. I think we're really -- we're still in a growth mode. We're just looking more granularly at individual businesses that are underperforming relative to expectations -- our expectations, and we're just trying to be thoughtful business managers as we do that.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the CBRE fourth quarter earnings call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to your host, Steve Iaco, with Investor Relations. Thank you. You may
componenttext:
Greetings, and welcome to the CBRE fourth quarter earnings call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to your host, Steve Iaco, with Investor Relations. Thank you. You may now begin.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome to CBRE's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Earlier today, we issued a press release announcing our financial results for the quarter and full year. This release is posted on the homepage of our website, cbre.com. This c
componenttext:
Thank you, and welcome to CBRE's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Earlier today, we issued a press release announcing our financial results for the quarter and full year. This release is posted on the homepage of our website, cbre.com. This conference call is being webcast through the Investor Relations section of our website. You can also find there a presentation slide deck, which you can use to follow along with our prepared remarks. An audio archive of the webcast will be posted to the website later today, and a transcript of our call will be posted tomorrow.
Now please turn to the slide labeled Forward-Looking Statements. This presentation contains statements that are forward-looking within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These include statements regarding CBRE's future growth momentum, operations, business outlook, financial performance, market share, earnings and adjusted EPS expectations for 2016. These statements should be considered to be estimates only, and actual results may ultimately differ from these estimates. Except to the extent required by securities laws, we undertake no obligation to update or publicly revise any forward-looking statements we may make today.
For a full discussion of the risks and other factors that may impact any forward-looking statements, please refer to our fourth quarter earnings report filed on Form 8-K, our quarterly report on Form 10-Q for the quarter ended September 30, 2015, and our most recent annual report on Form 10-K. These reports are filed with the SEC and available at sec.gov.
During this presentation, we may make certain statements that refer to non-GAAP financial measures as defined by SEC regulations. Where required by these regulations, we have provided reconciliations of these measures to what we believe are the most directly comparable GAAP measures. These reconciliations, together with explanations of these measures, can be found within the Appendix of this presentation.
Please turn to Slide 3. Participating on our call today are Bob Sulentic, our President and Chief Executive Officer; Jim Groch, our Chief Financial Officer; and Gil Borok, our Deputy Chief Financial Officer and Chief Accounting Officer.
Please turn to Slide 4 as I turn the call over to Bob.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve, and good morning, everyone. 2015 was another year of exceptional performance for CBRE, and this strong performance continued through the fourth quarter. For both periods, we set new company records for revenue and adjusted earnings and d
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve, and good morning, everyone. 2015 was another year of exceptional performance for CBRE, and this strong performance continued through the fourth quarter. For both periods, we set new company records for revenue and adjusted earnings and drove double-digit growth. We're the first firm in our sector to exceed $10 billion in revenue and $1.4 billion in normalized EBITDA, and we attained these milestones while making strategic gains across CBRE.
Notably, our occupier outsourcing business is materially stronger with the acquisition of the Global Workplace Solutions business. We have an unrivaled ability to self-performed facilities management services around the world. In capital markets, we made market share gains around the globe. We acquired 9 leading companies in 2015, enhancing our capabilities in energy management, retail data analytics, capital markets and consulting.
We had our third straight year of outsized recruiting gains as hundreds of new senior brokerage and capital markets professionals, net of departures, elected to join our team. The average production of people joining our team is 3x higher than those who leave. We opened our 30th new state-of-the-art, alternative workplace office, providing our people with a collaborative and innovative work environment.
Finally, we ended the year with a balance sheet that is stronger than at any time in recent history, highlighted by investment grade credit ratings. We thank our more than 70,000 employees for an excellent year in 2015 and for their commitment to our clients. 
Now Jim will take you through our results in greater detail.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bob. Please turn to Slide 5. As you've seen in our press release, CBRE's growth in 2015 was outstanding: revenue rose 20% to $10.9 billion; fee revenue increased 14% to $7.7 billion; normalized EBITDA rose 21% to $1.4 billion; and adjusted EPS
componenttext:
Thank you, Bob. Please turn to Slide 5. As you've seen in our press release, CBRE's growth in 2015 was outstanding: revenue rose 20% to $10.9 billion; fee revenue increased 14% to $7.7 billion; normalized EBITDA rose 21% to $1.4 billion; and adjusted EPS was up 22% to $2.05 this year. Profitability was strong with an 18.3% normalized EBITDA margin on fee revenue in 2015, up approximately 110 basis points from 2014. This performance was achieved in spite of significant headwinds from currency movements. 
Our 3 regional service segments achieved a 27% increase in normalized EBITDA with a margin on fee revenue of 16.5%, up 100 basis points for the year. 
Bob mentioned the strength of our balance sheet. Despite investing approximately $1.6 billion in 9 acquisitions during the year, we ended 2015 with no outstanding borrowings on our $2.6 billion revolving credit facility, $470 million of available cash in short-term investments and net debt of just under 1.6x normalized EBITDA.
Please turn to Slide 6 for a look at full year revenue growth by line of business. Our businesses continued to exhibit excellent broad-based momentum in 2015. Revenue from contractual sources totaled $6 billion. Contractual fee revenue was $2.9 billion, up 29% in local currency or 14% without the contributions from the acquired Global Workplace Solutions business. Leasing surpassed $2.5 billion of global revenue, up 11% in local currency.
The Capital markets business, property sales and mortgage services exceeded $2.1 billion in revenue and achieved 20% growth in local currency. The multiyear shift towards a more stable recurring business mix continued in 2015. Contractual fee revenue plus leasing, which is largely recurring, totaled 70%.
Please turn to Slide 7, where we will shift our attention from the full year to a review of our financial performance in Q4. 
Revenue and adjusted earnings growth for the quarter was very strong. Fee revenue improved 23% in local currency and 10% without the contribution from the acquired Global Workplace Solutions business. This growth was achieved on top of an exceptionally strong Q4 2014 when revenue increased 28% versus Q4 2013.
Normalized EBITDA for the quarter totaled $518 million, a 26% increase from last year's Q4, with 31% increase in local currency. Our profit margin also improved significantly. At 20.3%, our normalized EBITDA margin on fee revenue increased 130 basis points over prior year Q4. Adjusted earnings per share increased 19% to $0.81 for the quarter. 
Q4 2015 normalized EBITDA reflects the following adjustments: $26 million of carried interest expense, which we will recognize in future periods when we record associated revenue. This aligns with timing of expense and revenue recognition; $24 million of integration costs related to the acquisition of Global Workplace Solutions; and $40 million incurred to eliminate costs to enhance margins going forward. 
Please turn to Slide 8, where we will review Q4 results for our 3 regional services segments, all in local currency. Fee revenue increased 17% in the Americas as every business line exhibited growth. In EMEA, fee revenue improved 36% as we saw healthy gains across the region, particularly in Germany, the Netherlands, Spain, Switzerland and the United Kingdom. In Asia Pacific, fee revenue rose 27%, with Australia, Greater China and India setting the pace for growth.
Absent the contributions from the acquired Global Workplace Solutions business, fee revenue rose 9% in the Americas, 12% in EMEA and 11% in Asia Pacific. Normalized EBITDA increased 9% for the Americas, 45% for EMEA and 24% for Asia Pacific. Q4 normalized EBITDA margin on fee revenue for the 3 regions combined was 16.3%.
Please turn to Slide 9 for a review of the performance of our major global lines of business in Q4. All percentage increases are in local currency. For the company as a whole, contractual fee revenue plus leasing, which is largely recurring, totaled 73% of fee revenue for the quarter. Occupier outsourcing fee revenue more than doubled with the acquisition of Global Workplace Solutions.
Excluding contributions from this acquisition, occupier outsourcing continued to exhibit strong double-digit growth with a 19% increase in fee revenue. Asset Services had a strong quarter. Fee revenues increased 12% with notable growth in EMEA and the Americas. Investment Management also had a strong quarter. Revenue rose 22%, driven by carried interest on property dispositions, reflecting strong returns generated for fund investors.
Our Evaluations business grew revenue 9%. Leasing revenue rose 8% growth in the United States, which reflects a solid performance on top of an exceptionally strong 28% year-over-year increase in the fourth quarter of 2014. Global growth and leasing was paced by a 22% increase in Europe, notably France and the United Kingdom as well as strong contributions from Canada and Mexico.
Our capital markets business remained highly active globally, although growth rates slowed from earlier in the year. Global property sales rose 7% after accounting for a decline in market volumes from the United Kingdom. The global growth rate in Q4, excluding the United Kingdom was 13%. Investor interest in the United Kingdom remained strong, with cap rates stable and rental rates increasing in Q4, but we are seeing capital migrate to Continental Europe as local economies there strengthen and property yields are higher.
In the United States, our sales revenues grew 10% as we once again gained significant market share according to RCA. Commercial mortgage services revenue increased 6%. As expected, gains from mortgage servicing rights with the U.S. government-sponsored enterprises were flat as the agencies reached the regulatory caps on their lending.
However, loan originations were higher with banks, conduits and other debt capital sources. Our global loan servicing portfolio totaled $135 billion at year-end.
Please turn to Slide 10 regarding our occupier outsourcing business, which is reported within the 3 regional services segments. Even without the benefit of the acquired Global Workplace Solutions business, 2015 was a record year in terms of occupier outsourcing contracts. We brought on board more new clients and importantly expanded our service scope for more existing clients than ever before. In addition, we continue to make meaningful inroads in Europe and Asia as well as in key verticals like healthcare, data centers and life sciences.
Feedback from our clients has exceeded our expectations, and we are on course to materially complete client facing integration activities over the next 60 days.
Please turn to Slide 11 regarding our Global Investment Management segment. Revenue rose 22% in local currency and normalized EBITDA nearly doubled, fueled by $30 million of carried interest tied to significant returns for our clients on property dispositions. The strong performance of our investment programs relative to industry benchmarks continues to help us attract capital. New equity commitments totaled $7 billion in 2015. 
In Q4, Assets Under Management grew by $3 billion to $89 billion after a $1.1 billion drag from currency movement. For the year, AUM was up $1.9 billion in local currency, but down $1.6 billion when converted into U.S. dollars.
Please turn to Slide 12 regarding our Development Services segment. As anticipated, Development Services had a very strong quarter. Several large asset sales resulted in EBITDA of nearly $75 million for Q4. Development projects in-process totaled $6.7 billion at year-end 2015, up $1.3 billion from 2014. The pipeline inventory totaled $3.6 billion, down $0.4 billion as projects converted to in-process. 
Please turn to Slide 13. I will conclude my remarks by reiterating 3 points that highlight the financial strength of the business. Normalized EBITDA was up 21% for the year and 26% for the quarter. We achieved a margin on fee revenue of 18.3% for the year, and our available liquidity exceeds $3 billion. 
Now please turn to Slide 14 as I turn the call back to Bob for closing remarks.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. From all you've heard today, it should be clear that CBRE has a sustainable competitive advantage. Our leading global brand and strong culture help us to attract and keep tremendous talent in highly desirable clients. Investments in our platf
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim. From all you've heard today, it should be clear that CBRE has a sustainable competitive advantage. Our leading global brand and strong culture help us to attract and keep tremendous talent in highly desirable clients. Investments in our platform, especially in technology and data analytics, are helping our people to create more value for these clients. Our revenue base is more stable and stickier than ever before.
For 2016, we expect occupier outsourcing to continue its track record of strong performance. We anticipate low double-digit revenue growth this year before the contributions from the acquired Global Workplace Solutions business. Leasing revenue should increase at a high single-digit rate as we continue to gain market share. Our capital markets businesses, which consist of property sales and mortgage services, are most influenced by the financial markets, and volumes can be hard to predict quarter-to-quarter. 
However, we believe that the strong fundamentals and the value that real estate offers relative to other asset classes will continue to draw global capital to real estate in 2016. We estimate our capital markets revenue will grow to rate in the mid- to high single digits. Normalized EBITDA from our combined principal businesses, Global Investment Management and Development Services is anticipated to be flat to slightly down in 2016, reflecting a very strong 2015.
The shift to a more stable recurring business mix will continue as our financial results include a full year contribution from the acquired Global Workplace Solutions business. Even with this shift in business mix, in 2016, we expect our industry-leading margin on fee revenue to approximate 17%. While we are mindful of concerns about China's slowing growth and the effect of lower oil prices, fundamentals in our sector remain on solid footing. We're positioned for another strong year in 2016, but are maintaining flexibility in case the economy weakens.
Our outlook is based on economists consensus view that the global economy will maintain its modest rate of growth in 2016. We anticipate double-digit growth again this year supported by continued gains in market share and expect to achieve adjusted earnings per share in the range of $2.27 to $2.37 for 2016. This equates to a growth rate of 13% at the midpoint of our guidance.
With that, operator, we'll open the lines for questions.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: Anthony, this is Jim Groch. Yes, we said that we expect for the year that it'll be flat to down slightly combined for those 2 businesses, which would include any promote income. And then also in the Investment Management slide, you can see we break out promote revenue for that business, so you can see that separately. And then, Anthony, I would also just highlight for you that if you're trying to get to kind of the underlying performance of the 3 regional services businesses, the performance in Q4 and for the year for the 3 regional services businesses was very strong. So EBITDA in the 3 regional service businesses, which would not include Development or Investment Management, was up 19% in local currency for the year, 14% in USD -- I'm sorry, for the quarter, 19% in local currency for the quarter, 14% in USD.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttextpreview: Yes, we have -- we can't forecast, obviously, gains or losses for hedging positions because that'll have to -- the currencies will determine that for us as we see movement throughout the year. So we don't have any -- so there is a good bit of headwind bak
componenttext: Yes, we have -- we can't forecast, obviously, gains or losses for hedging positions because that'll have to -- the currencies will determine that for us as we see movement throughout the year. So we don't have any -- so there is a good bit of headwind baked into our forecast. As you know, the dollar strengthened throughout the year, and we don't have any currency -- any hedging gains in our guidance.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

Is that built into your guidance or does that mean that you're prepared to cut costs? Just trying to understand what the thought process is there.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, part of that comment was related to the broader range than we normally provide. We normally, as you know, Anthony, provide a $0.05 range. We provided a dime range this year for earnings. And then as it relates to the ongoing operations of our busine
componenttext: Well, part of that comment was related to the broader range than we normally provide. We normally, as you know, Anthony, provide a $0.05 range. We provided a dime range this year for earnings. And then as it relates to the ongoing operations of our business, we'll make choices about growth based on -- an investment based on how we see the year unfold as you would expect us to do. So that's really what we're talking about there.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just as of now and just to think about your outlook, you mentioned using your guidepost as economists' views. Just curious like, if anything's changed since your Business Review Day in November in terms of how you're seeing clients behave o
componenttext: Okay. And then just as of now and just to think about your outlook, you mentioned using your guidepost as economists' views. Just curious like, if anything's changed since your Business Review Day in November in terms of how you're seeing clients behave or seeing demand, either regionally or by business segment, if that's decelerated, stayed about the same or just how you're feeling about that outside of perhaps maybe what the economists are calling for?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes -- no, outside of what the economists are talking about, what we're seeing with our clients is what you see in the guidance we gave by line of business. It's an active marketplace for what we do. We're a month into the year, and its the slowest mon
componenttext: Yes -- no, outside of what the economists are talking about, what we're seeing with our clients is what you see in the guidance we gave by line of business. It's an active marketplace for what we do. We're a month into the year, and its the slowest month of the year, so you can't draw any conclusions. We've reflected what we believe kind of the collective view of our people and our people on The Street so to speak and our research people and our economists think and that's all wound up in the guidance we gave by line of business.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brad Burke with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brad Burke with Goldman Sachs.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you'd maybe spend more time just talking about the durability of your business as it stands currently in the event of an economic downturn, considering what we're all seeing in public equity markets and headlines over the last few months. May
componenttext: I was hoping you'd maybe spend more time just talking about the durability of your business as it stands currently in the event of an economic downturn, considering what we're all seeing in public equity markets and headlines over the last few months. Maybe you can give us some metrics to think about on how your business would perform if we were to have a recession and how that compares with what we saw during the last recession?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as you know, I think the business is a dramatically different business than existed back in say, 2006 or '07 before the last recession. Capital markets, which is the piece with more variability, it's more economically sensitive, it's a much smaller
componenttext: Well, as you know, I think the business is a dramatically different business than existed back in say, 2006 or '07 before the last recession. Capital markets, which is the piece with more variability, it's more economically sensitive, it's a much smaller part of the overall business; the contractual revenues, in particular, asset management and facility management, generally are either stable; or in the case of Asset Services, countercyclical, make up a much, much larger percentage of the business. And that's growing and will continue to grow as the results -- as the acquisition shows up in our full year numbers. So I think the business is just a different business than existed at that time. The other comment I would make is our balance sheet is a dramatically different balance sheet than existed at that time because we have enormous liquidity. We have very, very few -- very, very small amounts of maturities coming out for the next several years. So we are, I think, nicely poised to take advantage of opportunities. There are parts of our business that will be impacted if we have -- if we go into a recession, but overall, I think, we'll see tremendous opportunities to take advantage of as well.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And maybe talking about the opportunities, since M&A has been such a focus, can you talk about the flexibility you're looking to maintain? Does that imply potential slowdown in incremental M&A activity? And also when you look at M&A targets, are you seein
componenttext: And maybe talking about the opportunities, since M&A has been such a focus, can you talk about the flexibility you're looking to maintain? Does that imply potential slowdown in incremental M&A activity? And also when you look at M&A targets, are you seeing any of the weakness that we're seeing in the public equity markets begin to be reflected in the private M&A multiples that you would be looking at?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brad, this is Bob. When we talk about the opportunities we're going to see in a downturn and how we're positioned relative to the last cycle, as Jim said, not only is our balance sheet dramatically more compelling, we've made a lot of investments in
componenttext: Yes, Brad, this is Bob. When we talk about the opportunities we're going to see in a downturn and how we're positioned relative to the last cycle, as Jim said, not only is our balance sheet dramatically more compelling, we've made a lot of investments in our business that make this a better place for people to come to. Infill acquisitions want to be here more, brokers want to be here more, because of the way we can support them through the capabilities we have. And as a result, we think in a downturn, not only will we have the financial dry powder to invest, we'll have a platform that will be more attractive to different types of targets, people and businesses. And that proposition we think is really exciting for our company.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just the thoughts on incremental M&A at this point, would -- for fill-in acquisitions, would we expect you to continue the pace that we've seen over the course of 2015?
componenttext: Okay. And just the thoughts on incremental M&A at this point, would -- for fill-in acquisitions, would we expect you to continue the pace that we've seen over the course of 2015?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we're just going to have to see how that plays out. We continue to be very disciplined. We do still have a nice, strong volume of infill M&A, as strong as we've seen in the past. But we are selective around fit, and we're very careful around prici
componenttext: I think we're just going to have to see how that plays out. We continue to be very disciplined. We do still have a nice, strong volume of infill M&A, as strong as we've seen in the past. But we are selective around fit, and we're very careful around pricing.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And somewhat related to that, are you able to say with the balance sheet being at 1.6x EBITDA now, what the guidance range that you've given today would imply for year-end 2016 leverage levels?
