headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the CBRE Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Steve Iaco, Investor Relations. Thank you. You may be
componenttext:
Greetings, and welcome to the CBRE Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.
It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Steve Iaco, Investor Relations. Thank you. You may begin.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome to CBRE's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call.Earlier today, we issued a press release announcing our financial results for the quarter and first half of the year. This release is posted on the home page of our website, c
componenttext:
Thank you, and welcome to CBRE's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call.
Earlier today, we issued a press release announcing our financial results for the quarter and first half of the year. This release is posted on the home page of our website, cbre.com. This conference call is being webcast through the Investor Relations section of our website. There, you can find a presentation slide deck, which you can use to follow along with our prepared remarks. An audio archive of the webcast will be posted to the website later today, and a transcript of our call will be posted tomorrow.
Now please turn to slide labeled Forward-looking Statements. This presentation contains statements that are forward-looking within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These include statements regarding CBRE's future growth momentum, operations, market share, business outlook and financial performance expectations. These statements should be considered estimates only, and actual results may ultimately differ from these estimates. Except to the extent required by securities laws, we undertake no obligation to update or publicly revise any forward-looking statements we may make today. For a full discussion of the risks and other factors that may impact any forward-looking statements, please refer to our second quarter earnings report furnished on Form 8-K and our most recent quarterly and annual reports on Form 10-Q and Form 10-K. These results are filed with the SEC and available at sec.gov.
During this presentation, we may make certain statements that are referring to non-GAAP financial measures as defined by SEC regulations. Where required by these regulations, we've provided reconciliations of these measures to what we believe are the most directly comparable GAAP measures. Those reconciliations, together with explanations of these measures, can be found within the appendix of this presentation.
Please turn to Slide 3. Participating on our call today are Bob Sulentic, our President and Chief Executive Officer; Jim Groch, our Chief Financial Officer; and Gil Borok, our Deputy Chief Financial Officer and Chief Accounting Officer.
Now please turn to Slide 4 as I turn the call over to Bob.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve, and good morning, everyone. CBRE posted another quarter of strong growth on the top and bottom lines with a 24% increase in adjusted EPS. This growth came amid an uncertain macro environment and, notably, a time when global property sale
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve, and good morning, everyone. CBRE posted another quarter of strong growth on the top and bottom lines with a 24% increase in adjusted EPS. This growth came amid an uncertain macro environment and, notably, a time when global property sales volumes market-wide have pulled back from a robust 2015. The diversity of CBRE's service offering is especially important in the current market environment. Our performance for the quarter was supported by strong growth in mortgage services, reflecting continued debt capital flows into commercial real estate and in occupier outsourcing, which, once again, grew revenue strongly even before contributions from the acquired Global WorkPlace Solutions business.
Leasing was also up nicely in the Americas and Asia Pacific, and our Investment Management and Development Services businesses produced solid EBITDA gains for the quarter.
Jim will take you through all of this in detail shortly. Before he does, I want to address the UK's vote to leave the European Union.
Please turn to Slide 5. CBRE, like the rest of the commercial real estate services industry, was affected by the high degree of uncertainty in the U.K. market leading up to the referendum on June 23. This can be seen in the nearly 40% drop in U.K. market-wide property sales volumes in Q2, according to CBRE research. However, the effect on CBRE's U.K. revenue was materially less pronounced. In local currency, CBRE's total U.K. fee revenue increased 12%. Without the contributions from the acquired Global WorkPlace Solutions business, U.K. fee revenue in local currency was just 5% below Q2 2015, which had been up 32% over Q2 of the prior year. This performance highlights how significantly our U.K. business has evolved in recent years. During the first half of 2016, occupier outsourcing and property management, which is sticky recurring revenue, accounted for 69% of U.K. fee revenue versus just 19% in the first half of 2013. This shift in our U.K. revenue mix has been driven by our acquisitions of Norland in late 2013 and Global WorkPlace Solutions in September 2015 and positions us well as the U.K. goes about resetting its relationship with the European Union.
Please turn to Slide 6. CBRE expects continued near-term hesitancy among occupiers about space decisions in the U.K., particularly in London. We expect a modest increase in property yields, reflecting the higher perceived risk of holding U.K. property. However, this increase may be temporary, especially for top-tier assets, due to the inherent attractiveness of the U.K. market. In addition, the decline in the value of sterling against the U.S. dollar should provide some incremental support for foreign investments into the U.K. over time. We also anticipate a delay in some office development activity, which should provide longer-term support for property prices as well as rents, particularly in Central London, where availability stands at just 3%.
We are monitoring Brexit-related developments closely. There's a long road ahead, but the swift resolution of the political leadership in Britain is an encouraging sign. Given our clear leadership position, CBRE is well positioned to capitalize on opportunities in the U.K. and across Europe. We are firmly focused on continuing to support our European business and clients.
Now I'll turn the call over to Jim, who will discuss our second quarter results in detail.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. Please turn to Slide 7 for an overview of our financial results. Fee revenue rose 20% in local currency to $2.1 billion or 3% organic growth in fee revenue without the contributions from the acquired Global WorkPlace Solutions business and ot
componenttext:
Thanks, Bob. Please turn to Slide 7 for an overview of our financial results. Fee revenue rose 20% in local currency to $2.1 billion or 3% organic growth in fee revenue without the contributions from the acquired Global WorkPlace Solutions business and other M&A. Adjusted EBITDA for the quarter totaled $360 million, a 19% increase in U.S. dollars from last year's Q2. Margin on fee revenue was 17%. Adjusted earnings per share increased 24% to $0.52 for the quarter. Q2's results include $4 million of net benefit to adjusted EBITDA from currency movement, including gains on hedges. This compares to a net unfavorable impact of $40 million in the second quarter of 2015. Q2 2016 adjusted EBITDA of $360 million includes adjustments for $28 million of integration costs relating to the acquisition of Global WorkPlace Solutions and $27 million incurred in connection with cost elimination program that we discussed in the prior 2 quarters.
Please turn to Slide 8 regarding Q2 results for our 3 regional service segments, all in local currency. Fee revenue increased 18% in the Americas, 31% in EMEA and 18% in Asia Pacific. Without contributions from the acquisition of Global WorkPlace Solutions, fee revenue increased 6% in the Americas and was essentially flat in both EMEA and Asia Pacific.
Please turn to Slide 9 for a review of our business mix. Our business mix continues to evolve towards greater contractual revenue. For the company as a whole, contractual fee revenue was 44% of total fee revenue, up from 34% in Q2 2015 and 19% in Q2 2006.
Please turn to Slide 10 for a review of our major global lines of business in Q2. All percentages increases are in local currency. Occupier outsourcing continued to exhibit strong growth. Global fee revenue was up 118%, aided by the acquisition of Global WorkPlace Solutions. Without contributions from this acquisition, fee revenue rose 10%. Commercial mortgage services had a very good quarter with revenue up 14%, led by private lenders, particularly banks, and continued growth with government-sponsored enterprises. Leasing achieved good growth in the Americas, which is up 8%, and Asia Pacific, which rose 7%. We continue to benefit from the influx of producers choosing to join CBRE.
In the Americas, Canada, Mexico and the U.S. all turned in healthy performances, while Asia Pac was led by Greater China, India and New Zealand. Leasing was down 11% in EMEA as growth in Belgium, Germany and The Netherlands and Spain partially offset a decline in the U.K. Property sales revenue rose 2% in the Americas, while EMEA and Asia Pacific both declined 16%. This compares with an exceptionally strong Q2 2015 when year-on-year growth rates were 25% in the Americas, 62% in EMEA and 24% in Asia Pacific.
Q2 2016 property sales revenue in the U.K. declined by approximately 1/3. CBRE continued to make gains in property sales as evidenced by our 150 basis point market share increase in the U.S. during Q2, according to RCA.
Fee revenue from property management services, which we call asset services, increased by 7%. Valuation revenue was essentially unchanged.
Please turn to Slide 11 regarding our occupier outsourcing business, which we reported within the 3 regional service segments. Finance interest in our outsourcing offering remains high. This can be seen in the 96 total contracts we signed during Q2, including 37 with new clients. Notably, more than 1/3 of these new clients were in EMEA and Asia Pacific. Evidence to the outsourcing is gaining more traction in overseas markets.
Our engagements often span multiple geographies and services. CBRE is well positioned to serve complex, multi-market requirements with our clients with the acquired Global WorkPlace Solutions expertise firmly embedded in our outsourcing business.
Please turn to Slide 12 regarding our Global Investment Management segment. Adjusted EBITDA for this business line increased to $26 million. The business continues to attract significant capital commitments. We raised $1.8 billion of new -- in new equity in Q2 and $7.1 billion in the trailing 12 months. Assets under management totaled $88.6 billion, up $3.9 billion from a year ago in local currency. However, all but $200 million of this increase was offset by foreign currency movement over the past year.
Please turn to Slide 13 regarding our Development Services segment. Strong performance in this business continued in Q2. Adjusted EBITDA totaled $19 million for the quarter, while pro forma revenue, which includes gains on real estate sales, equity earnings and noncontrolling interests, increased to $46 million. These strong results in the quarter were helped by the timing of asset sales. We note that these development asset sales accounting for -- accounted for the vast majority of our equity earnings for the quarter. Due to the timing of project sales, we expect results for the remainder of the year to be heavily weighted to the fourth quarter, with a significantly lighter third quarter. Development projects in process totaled $7.1 billion, up $1.1 billion from Q2 2015. The pipeline of $3 billion was down $700 million from a year ago as projects converted from pipeline to in-process.
Please turn to Slide 14. Before I turn the call back to Bob, I'd like to briefly highlight our results for the first half of 2016. These results are strong, including growth rates of 24% in fee revenue in local currency, 17% in adjusted EBITDA and 21% in adjusted earnings per share. This growth is particularly notable coming at a time when average earnings of S&P 500 companies are expected to decline in Q2 2016 for the fifth consecutive quarter.
Please turn to Slide 15 for Bob's closing remarks.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. As you've seen, our business has performed very well in the first half of 2016, even with a decline in market-wide property sales volumes compared to a year ago. It is important to note that market fundamentals in commercial real estate remai
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim. As you've seen, our business has performed very well in the first half of 2016, even with a decline in market-wide property sales volumes compared to a year ago. It is important to note that market fundamentals in commercial real estate remain in good shape, with the impact of Brexit largely limited to property transactions activity in the U.K., and we anticipate solid earnings growth for the year. Looking ahead, we are adjusting our outlook for the remainder of the year. This is due principally to the impact of Brexit on U.K. property transaction volumes and less visibility around the timing of the realization of certain tenants in our Global Investment Management business and Development Services business. These factors have caused us to reduce our earnings guidance by 3% at the top end of our range and by 5% at the bottom end. This results in expected adjusted EPS for the calendar year of $2.15 to $2.30, which represents solid growth of approximately 9% at the midpoint of the range. We see adjusted EPS in the second half of 2016 more weighted to Q4 rather than Q3 compared with our customary progression of earnings throughout the year.
As the clear market leader, CBRE is well positioned to further extend our competitive advantage in the marketplace. Our ongoing talent and technology initiatives, collaborative culture, market-leading service offering and financial strength uniquely position us to satisfy clients' growing demand for our services.
With that, operator, we'll open the lines for questions.

componenttext: Wanted to ask about the guidance. The initial guidance you gave us for the year indicated that leasing was going to grow high single digits; capital markets, mid- to high single digits; outsourcing, low double digits; and your principal business EBITDA will be flat to slightly down. So the updated guidance that you're giving us today, can you give us an update on how those expectations have changed as they're reflected in the full year guidance?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Jim, sure. Yes, we're not changing any to specific guidance that we gave early in the year and actually think that generally, we still anticipate all those ranges that we gave that will perform within the ranges provided at the beginning of the year.
componenttext: It's Jim, sure. Yes, we're not changing any to specific guidance that we gave early in the year and actually think that generally, we still anticipate all those ranges that we gave that will perform within the ranges provided at the beginning of the year. If you look at the update on our guidance at the midpoint, it's -- the range is a little wider, and at the midpoint, we're down 4%. And I think as we kind of referenced, a little more than half of that is really tied to Brexit impact on U.K. transactions. And then some of the widening and a bit that's left is in there around just some timing risk around the realization of incentives in our Global Investment Management and Development Services and then just some very minor tweaks to our forecast internally.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And staying with the U.K., Slide 5, I appreciate the detail on the U.K. business. Can you give us a sense of the exposure that you have within your principal businesses? While I assume there's not much for Development Services, but interested in Inv
componenttext: Okay. And staying with the U.K., Slide 5, I appreciate the detail on the U.K. business. Can you give us a sense of the exposure that you have within your principal businesses? While I assume there's not much for Development Services, but interested in Investment Management exposure.

componenttext: Yes. We very, very -- there's no Development Services really, and Investment Management is mostly core portfolio funds in separate accounts. So very, very little exposure there.

componenttext: Okay. And the headlines that we're seeing about the open-end funds businesses in the U.K., the daily liquidity retail-oriented products, I realize that you guys are going after a different segment, but still wanted to check if you're expecting any sort of spillover impact from the pressures that we see on those daily liquidity vehicles.

componenttextpreview: In terms of sales and leasing, it seems like you guys had another quarter of share gains, at least relative to the third-party data. Can you talk about whether you think that's happening from more wins or this is headcount? Or what do you think is driving
componenttext: In terms of sales and leasing, it seems like you guys had another quarter of share gains, at least relative to the third-party data. Can you talk about whether you think that's happening from more wins or this is headcount? Or what do you think is driving that?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tony, this is Bob. Headcount is certainly part of it. We've talked over the last several quarters about the gains we've made over the last 2 to 3 years in recruiting. That has continued into this year, although at a slower pace, partially because some of
componenttext: Tony, this is Bob. Headcount is certainly part of it. We've talked over the last several quarters about the gains we've made over the last 2 to 3 years in recruiting. That has continued into this year, although at a slower pace, partially because some of the pricing we've seen out there for recruiting we don't think makes sense. So our recruiting is down by about 1/3 this year. The other thing that's benefiting us is some of the strategic things we've done with those businesses. And notably, we've grown our small asset class business materially on the sales side. And on the advisory and transaction services side of our occupier client offering, we've integrated our outsourcing business with our local brokerage business and added a bunch of advisory capabilities that have really allowed us to take on a lot of account business beyond what we were ever able to do before and offer things to our clients that go beyond what we were able to offer before. And that's coming through on our numbers, and it's coming through on our numbers for outsourcing business and our local brokerage business or local leasing business, and we're taking market share as a result.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And can you help us at all with thinking about just the incremental margins for sales and leasing as we kind of look ahead?

componenttext: We really haven't been providing guidance around incremental margins. And part of that is it depends on the trajectory of the business. So we haven't been that specific.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then if I look at your cost elimination program, you guys spent, I think, $27 million on this in the second quarter, and that was up from about $8 million or $9 million, I think, in the first quarter. How much do you think you're going to drive in t
componenttext: Okay. Then if I look at your cost elimination program, you guys spent, I think, $27 million on this in the second quarter, and that was up from about $8 million or $9 million, I think, in the first quarter. How much do you think you're going to drive in terms of run rate savings from the initiative? Like how much is left here because it seems like it's been extended since last quarter?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We haven't given specific guidance on where that's going. I would say, we mentioned that we started this program late last year. And at the time, we noted that just we've grown the business massively over the last 3 years. And when you do, eventually you
componenttext: We haven't given specific guidance on where that's going. I would say, we mentioned that we started this program late last year. And at the time, we noted that just we've grown the business massively over the last 3 years. And when you do, eventually you need to step back and look for pockets where you may have some inefficiency. And then we thought that it was a good time to kind of work on that. But I'd also highlight that all those savings don't drop to the bottom line because we do reinvest. While we're cutting costs in some areas, we are looking to reinvest in other areas where we think we'll get real leverage from our investments.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So if I -- and if I think about that, just to understand the numbers, like the $27 million you spent in the quarter on that stuff, like would that be in the $688 million of OpEx? Or is it somewhere else? Or how do we think about that?
componenttext: Okay. So if I -- and if I think about that, just to understand the numbers, like the $27 million you spent in the quarter on that stuff, like would that be in the $688 million of OpEx? Or is it somewhere else? Or how do we think about that?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tony, it's Gil. In the P&L with the press release, the GAAP P&L, it would mostly be in OpEx. In normalized EBITDA or adjusted EBITDA purposes, it's adjusted out. But that is where you'd see it mostly in the GAAP P&L.
componenttext: Tony, it's Gil. In the P&L with the press release, the GAAP P&L, it would mostly be in OpEx. In normalized EBITDA or adjusted EBITDA purposes, it's adjusted out. But that is where you'd see it mostly in the GAAP P&L.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got it. And then on outsourcing, the -- if we take GWS out of the mix, it looked like the organic growth may be slowed a bit from 1Q into 2Q. How do you think about that the rest of the year? You've talked in the past about organically, that's still
componenttext: Okay. Got it. And then on outsourcing, the -- if we take GWS out of the mix, it looked like the organic growth may be slowed a bit from 1Q into 2Q. How do you think about that the rest of the year? You've talked in the past about organically, that's still running into the double digits. Is that still something we should expect? Or could that slow a bit perhaps because of the EMEA exposure and Brexit and so forth? Or how do you feel about that?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Tony, Brexit hasn't really impacted the growth of that business or the stability of that business. And we did achieve 13% organic growth in that business in the first half, very consistent with our expectations for the business, which are unchanged i
componenttext: Yes, Tony, Brexit hasn't really impacted the growth of that business or the stability of that business. And we did achieve 13% organic growth in that business in the first half, very consistent with our expectations for the business, which are unchanged in terms of the ongoing organic growth. We're extremely pleased with the way that business has grown year-to-date. By the way, it was double-digit growth in the second quarter, too, at 10%. There's a little inefficiency quarter-to-quarter. And we're quite excited about what we think the profile from continued growth of that business is.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jade Rahmani with KBW.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jade Rahmani with KBW.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Regarding the guidance and your comments about weighting more toward 4Q than 3Q relative to historical performance, can you maybe put some color around what the drivers of that are? Is that due to increased uncertainty in 3Q around capital markets volumes
componenttext: Regarding the guidance and your comments about weighting more toward 4Q than 3Q relative to historical performance, can you maybe put some color around what the drivers of that are? Is that due to increased uncertainty in 3Q around capital markets volumes that you expect to normalize in the fourth quarter? Or is it those incentive fee realizations?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there's nothing particularly driving it, really just the timing of whether it's carried interest in the Investment Management business or individual sales within the Development Services business. It can differ from year-to-year, from quarter-to-quar
componenttext: Yes, there's nothing particularly driving it, really just the timing of whether it's carried interest in the Investment Management business or individual sales within the Development Services business. It can differ from year-to-year, from quarter-to-quarter. We're ahead on activity year-to-date versus last year, and we just look at the timing on these when we see transactions coming in Q3 looks like it'll be light and Q4 looks like it will be strong. Although in comparison, the last year, Q4 was exceptionally strong. So we don't -- with Q4 at that type of activity will likely be down from Q4 of last year still. So Q3 will be light and just timing. Some deals we thought we were going to hit in Q3 happened in Q2 and looked like some others are actually going to hit in Q4 instead of 3.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of capital markets, what can you say about the level of visibility you currently have for 3Q and even 4Q given the timing? And how long it takes transactions to close? Would you say that you're assuming similar year-on-year revenue growth ex fore
componenttext: In terms of capital markets, what can you say about the level of visibility you currently have for 3Q and even 4Q given the timing? And how long it takes transactions to close? Would you say that you're assuming similar year-on-year revenue growth ex foreign currency impact that you've experienced in this quarter?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jade, we expect to end up the year in the ranges that we gave at the beginning of the year. And the one place that we're seeing things meaningfully different is no big shocker, it's the U.K, which is a sizable market with London. But we've worked har
componenttext: Yes, Jade, we expect to end up the year in the ranges that we gave at the beginning of the year. And the one place that we're seeing things meaningfully different is no big shocker, it's the U.K, which is a sizable market with London. But we've worked hard to get a handle on what our people around the world are working on, and we've done that again recently and feel pretty good about the ranges that we gave at the beginning of the year. So we're not changing anything in that regard.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the cash flow and capital management spend, can you quantify the amount of dollars you've spent on M&A this year or this quarter and what you expect going forward? And given your view of the cycle and perhaps recent stock performances, you might contem
componenttext: On the cash flow and capital management spend, can you quantify the amount of dollars you've spent on M&A this year or this quarter and what you expect going forward? And given your view of the cycle and perhaps recent stock performances, you might contemplate some sort of stock buyback or dividend as an alternative use of capital.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as far as use of capital, we're always looking carefully at how to apply our capital in the most favorable way possible for our shareholders. But we don't comment specifically on what we might do there. As far as dollar spent on M&A, those figures w
componenttext: Well, as far as use of capital, we're always looking carefully at how to apply our capital in the most favorable way possible for our shareholders. But we don't comment specifically on what we might do there. As far as dollar spent on M&A, those figures will be in the Q when that comes out.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And finally, just on headcount, can you comment on what the, perhaps, year-over-year organic growth rate was overall or in transaction professionals?
componenttext: And finally, just on headcount, can you comment on what the, perhaps, year-over-year organic growth rate was overall or in transaction professionals?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jade, we don't give specific headcount on our transaction professionals. But what I can say is that we've continued to bring on new producers in the investment sales, mortgage brokerage and leasing parts of our business at a very strong rate, althoug
componenttext: Yes, Jade, we don't give specific headcount on our transaction professionals. But what I can say is that we've continued to bring on new producers in the investment sales, mortgage brokerage and leasing parts of our business at a very strong rate, although off the last couple of peak years we've had by about 1/3. And we don't have any reason to believe that there'll be big variability in that pace for the balance of this year. We're watching very closely what's going on in the market. And we're seeing some what we consider foolish deals in the market, the kind of things that just aren't sustainable. And so we're staying clear of that activity. But again, we're having good success. It's impacting our growth in a positive way, and we expect that to continue.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brandon Dobell with William Blair.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brandon Dobell with William Blair.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Guys, I'll be going back to Slide 11 for a second, the occupier outsourcing. A couple of questions there. The 37 new clients, are those just new occupier outsourcing clients? Or are they new clients for CBRE as a whole?
componenttext: Guys, I'll be going back to Slide 11 for a second, the occupier outsourcing. A couple of questions there. The 37 new clients, are those just new occupier outsourcing clients? Or are they new clients for CBRE as a whole?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, let me -- I want to make sure I'm answering what you're asking, Brandon. So are you asking, are these clients that we've never done anything at all for before or just that we have not done outsourcing work for them before?
componenttext: Well, yes, let me -- I want to make sure I'm answering what you're asking, Brandon. So are you asking, are these clients that we've never done anything at all for before or just that we have not done outsourcing work for them before?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess kind of asking it in other way, I guess, would be helpful. Just trying to get a sense of when you talk about new, are these ones you're getting because you've already done business in someplace elsewhere in the world or leasing with, et cetera, or
componenttext: I guess kind of asking it in other way, I guess, would be helpful. Just trying to get a sense of when you talk about new, are these ones you're getting because you've already done business in someplace elsewhere in the world or leasing with, et cetera, or just purely new guys that have done nothing else for you before?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: These are new to the outsourcing business. I think when you ask the broader question, are they new to CBRE, we've done business with almost every major company in the world at some point through our transactional activity so -- over the years. So there's
componenttext: These are new to the outsourcing business. I think when you ask the broader question, are they new to CBRE, we've done business with almost every major company in the world at some point through our transactional activity so -- over the years. So there's almost nobody that we would do a new outsourcing account for that we've done nothing for ever before. But the count you're getting there is for new outsourcing accounts.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. And the expansion that you guys continue to sign at a pretty good clip, any sense of the order of magnitude of those contracts? And I guess, I'm looking at a secondary perspective, are we talking just more space, breadth of services? And is
componenttext: Got it. Okay. And the expansion that you guys continue to sign at a pretty good clip, any sense of the order of magnitude of those contracts? And I guess, I'm looking at a secondary perspective, are we talking just more space, breadth of services? And is there any marked difference between how those expansions may look in the U.S. versus EMEA?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: To that last question, I can't give you an answer off the top of my head. I can tell you that expansion is typically, there's a very typical pattern. We usually add services when we expand, so we'll start providing one service, and we'll typically add ano
componenttext: To that last question, I can't give you an answer off the top of my head. I can tell you that expansion is typically, there's a very typical pattern. We usually add services when we expand, so we'll start providing one service, and we'll typically add another service or 2 when we do good work for our clients. And it's also very typical that we will take on new geography, sometimes just within the United States or sometimes in other parts of the world. But those are the 2 things. And that's one of the beautiful things about this business. If you do good work for these clients, and we track the work we do for them very closely, there is almost always an opportunity to take on new services or new geography. And it's core to the strategy that Bill Concannon articulates for his people every day and drives with his people every day. As he would say it, win them, keep them, grow them. And that grow them is all about taking on new turf or adding new lines of business for him.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. Okay. And then final one for me, on the expense structure. Given what's going on in the U.K. in particular but just around Brexit, any acceleration or change in trajectory on how aggressively you guys are going after out of the expenses that have
componenttext: Got you. Okay. And then final one for me, on the expense structure. Given what's going on in the U.K. in particular but just around Brexit, any acceleration or change in trajectory on how aggressively you guys are going after out of the expenses that have gone or built up over the years through M&A or just some recognition of what that market looks like for next handful of quarters, particularly among, I guess, transaction support people but also just more broadly?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. No change there really. We haven't made any changes. I mean, look, I think it's important to emphasize that fundamentals for the markets generally, globally, outside of circumstances in the U.K. remain quite strong. And so we started with some cost ef
componenttext: No. No change there really. We haven't made any changes. I mean, look, I think it's important to emphasize that fundamentals for the markets generally, globally, outside of circumstances in the U.K. remain quite strong. And so we started with some cost efficiency work in Q4 of last year. We're making good progress on that. We're reinvesting some of those savings primarily in technology initiatives. And I'd also highlight, our margin on fee revenue in Q2, which is a medium-sized quarter, obviously, for the year, nowhere near Q4, just for the 3 regional businesses, was 16%. So the margins are good, and the margin overall is higher when you include the principal businesses. So I think we feel pretty good about where we are, and no major program being accelerated.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And as my kind of final one. In the conversations with customers in investment sales, property sales, how much have you heard people talk about -- or source of capital talk about shifting away from U.K. and Europe for a while and focusing on the U.S
componenttext: Okay. And as my kind of final one. In the conversations with customers in investment sales, property sales, how much have you heard people talk about -- or source of capital talk about shifting away from U.K. and Europe for a while and focusing on the U.S. given its kind of market liquidity and transparency, those kind of things? Or is it more just if you want to be in the U.K. and Europe, we're just going to take some time to, I think, settle out and we're not going to shift our focus on where the capital is going?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the U.K. and Europe are different for me. They're not one thing. So people are definitely pausing in the U.K. There's a few anecdotes about pausing in Europe but really not very much. I was over there a couple of weeks ago, and in general, we're not
componenttext: Well, the U.K. and Europe are different for me. They're not one thing. So people are definitely pausing in the U.K. There's a few anecdotes about pausing in Europe but really not very much. I was over there a couple of weeks ago, and in general, we're not seeing that on the continent. Here in the U.S., when you talk to our people in local markets, there's a bit of wishful thinking that we'll get incremental capital here as a result of what's happening in the U.K., but there is already a lot of capital aimed at the U.S. markets. And I would say that in aggregate, that's kind of what it was before, and the net-net of all of it is people that were going to invest in the U.K. are kind of waiting to see. And in the other big markets around the world, we haven't seen a meaningful impact yet.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Ridley-Lane with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Ridley-Lane with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you give us some details on the pace in which you're approaching GWS clients around potentially cross-selling leasing? Are you targeting those pitches around contract renewal dates? Are you targeting existing GWS clients where you already have a lar
componenttext: Could you give us some details on the pace in which you're approaching GWS clients around potentially cross-selling leasing? Are you targeting those pitches around contract renewal dates? Are you targeting existing GWS clients where you already have a large share of their leasing but not a company-wide contract? Just sort of wondering about the pace there.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, we, first and foremost, have made a very, very visible commitment to the clients that came over to that GWS acquisition that we are going to be riveted on transitioning the work we do for them now. And we have made clear to them that we're not in t
componenttext: David, we, first and foremost, have made a very, very visible commitment to the clients that came over to that GWS acquisition that we are going to be riveted on transitioning the work we do for them now. And we have made clear to them that we're not in there aggressively trying to do more for them in any different way than we have done historically. Now you know we have a very, very big leasing offering around the world. And we're talking to most companies in the world, most of the time about doing leasing work for them. Nothing about that has changed. But with regard to the relationship people on those accounts, they've almost exclusively focused on transitioning the accounts and doing great work form and measuring that work. That's going well. We have a lot of work to do in that area. We've gotten most of that integration work done. I will tell you that if you talk to Bill Concannon and his team, they'll tell you now that if things are starting to feel very different with those clients, those clients were becoming much more comfortable with them. We've had some very recent significant wins. The confidence that we can marry up all the pieces of that business and go to market as an integrated offering is growing pretty rapidly. So we think those opportunities are very, very good, but through the first 3 quarters of that acquisition transition, the focus has been on transitioning those accounts and really questioning the work that we've already been given from those clients.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. And then on the -- here in the United States, the issuance of commercial mortgage-backed securities has been weak so far in 2016. And as you talk to your capital markets professionals, is that having a negative impact? Or are there enough so
componenttext: Got it. Okay. And then on the -- here in the United States, the issuance of commercial mortgage-backed securities has been weak so far in 2016. And as you talk to your capital markets professionals, is that having a negative impact? Or are there enough sources of debt financing that it's not really impacting the U.S. capital markets volumes?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The mortgage business is doing quite well, it's up 14% for the quarter. And we're seeing lots of liquidity. And so I think there's been plenty of liquidity that fill that void, and it's not been an issue.
componenttext: The mortgage business is doing quite well, it's up 14% for the quarter. And we're seeing lots of liquidity. And so I think there's been plenty of liquidity that fill that void, and it's not been an issue.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And last one for me. Do you have any -- if FX rates stayed the same as they are today, do you have a rough estimate of what the benefit from FX hedges would be in 2016?
componenttext: Great. And last one for me. Do you have any -- if FX rates stayed the same as they are today, do you have a rough estimate of what the benefit from FX hedges would be in 2016?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: If the rates stay where they are now, then there should be no impact because we mark to market our hedge positions every quarter, and -- so that's how it would play out.
componenttext: If the rates stay where they are now, then there should be no impact because we mark to market our hedge positions every quarter, and -- so that's how it would play out.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So the benefit you saw in the second quarter was as of rates on June 30.
componenttext: Okay. So the benefit you saw in the second quarter was as of rates on June 30.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Mitch Germain with JMP Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mitch Germain with JMP Securities.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim, you guys have been on this pace of, call it, around 12-or-so tuck-in acquisitions per year. Any change in your appetite? Or does that still seem to be somewhat aligned with kind of the run rate that we should expect?
componenttext: Jim, you guys have been on this pace of, call it, around 12-or-so tuck-in acquisitions per year. Any change in your appetite? Or does that still seem to be somewhat aligned with kind of the run rate that we should expect?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mitch, it's a good question. Our M&A pipeline is quite active. But we did start to pull back on infill last year when we saw pricing in the marketplace increasing. So we're -- as always, we're very active in the market. We're looking for great companies,
componenttext: Mitch, it's a good question. Our M&A pipeline is quite active. But we did start to pull back on infill last year when we saw pricing in the marketplace increasing. So we're -- as always, we're very active in the market. We're looking for great companies, a great cultural fit, companies that are going to truly add capabilities to what we offer. But we will -- pricing matters, it does, and we will pull back from time to time and get back in when we see things be more in line with where we think they should be.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. Okay. And then just curious, it seems like we've seen a couple of assets rates in some of refinancings in the U.K. Maybe Bob, I mean, discussions that you're having with your team, does it seem like the pauses may be lifting a little in that mark
componenttext: Got you. Okay. And then just curious, it seems like we've seen a couple of assets rates in some of refinancings in the U.K. Maybe Bob, I mean, discussions that you're having with your team, does it seem like the pauses may be lifting a little in that market and things are moving slowly back to normal? Or you'll maybe just get a little of sense about momentum now?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I talked to Martin Samworth, the CEO of EMEA for our business, 2 days ago, and I asked him that question. And he said that, in fact, there was a distinct clawing back of the momentum that had been lost due to Brexit up until about a week ago when, as he p
componenttext: I talked to Martin Samworth, the CEO of EMEA for our business, 2 days ago, and I asked him that question. And he said that, in fact, there was a distinct clawing back of the momentum that had been lost due to Brexit up until about a week ago when, as he put it, everybody in Europe started going on vacation. And he thinks that legitimately, that there's been a turnaround, but the whole vacation season there is causing that turnaround to kind of slow for a while. But he's encouraged that when September comes around, that we'll see things -- that the momentum will reemerge.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is a follow-up question from Brad Burke with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question is a follow-up question from Brad Burke with Goldman Sachs.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one follow-up for me with regards to the AUM and the investment management business realizing that there have been a lot of FX headwinds to AUM growth. But based on what you're seeing now in terms of capital raising and the capital that you have yet
componenttext: Just one follow-up for me with regards to the AUM and the investment management business realizing that there have been a lot of FX headwinds to AUM growth. But based on what you're seeing now in terms of capital raising and the capital that you have yet to deploy, how we ought to be thinking about the AUM growth over the next year or so?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we'll continue to be in line with where -- what we've been doing over the last year or 2. But unfortunately, that growth continues to be offset generally by change of FX. So the growth has been quite good, but as you highlighted, the FX has tended
componenttext: I think we'll continue to be in line with where -- what we've been doing over the last year or 2. But unfortunately, that growth continues to be offset generally by change of FX. So the growth has been quite good, but as you highlighted, the FX has tended to offset most of it.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jade Rahmani with KBW.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jade Rahmani with KBW.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: When you quantify the percent of revenues from contractual revenue sources, can you give some color on what percentage of leasing transactions which are not contractual but would be considered recurring? Or historically, what percentage of leases, renewal
componenttext: When you quantify the percent of revenues from contractual revenue sources, can you give some color on what percentage of leasing transactions which are not contractual but would be considered recurring? Or historically, what percentage of leases, renewal, and you guys win that business?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So when we refer to contractual revenues, and we had a slide in our deck that kind of showed the change in the business and the degree which contractual revenues have increased as a percentage of the total, there are no leasing revenues in those num
componenttext: Okay. So when we refer to contractual revenues, and we had a slide in our deck that kind of showed the change in the business and the degree which contractual revenues have increased as a percentage of the total, there are no leasing revenues in those numbers. So they're -- you will hear us refer to leasing as being largely recurring over time. And -- but we dont include any of those revenues in the contractual section of what we refer to as contractual. As far as the percentage of deals we get renewals, I can't give you a figure -- an exact figure, but it's extremely high. And if we didn't get a renewal -- on the margin, if we or others aren't getting the renewals on their assignments, then we're picking up the other competitors' piece and vice versa, but that tends to be quite rare.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And in terms of EBITDA contribution from contractual revenue sources, is it similar to the percent of revenue or lower than that given the high margins that capital markets generate historically?
componenttext: And in terms of EBITDA contribution from contractual revenue sources, is it similar to the percent of revenue or lower than that given the high margins that capital markets generate historically?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We haven't been -- I guess the most we've said on that is that the contribution is closer than you would think because on a fee revenue basis, our contractual revenues include some of our lower-margin business in outsourcing management area and some of ou
componenttext: We haven't been -- I guess the most we've said on that is that the contribution is closer than you would think because on a fee revenue basis, our contractual revenues include some of our lower-margin business in outsourcing management area and some of our higher margin in investment management. So it's not quite equal between revenue and EBITDA, but it's not as far off as you might think.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So staying on the contractual business and the outsourcing since it's becoming so big and important for you all, can you take us inside a little bit and tell us, when you have a multi-year contract, you have a contractual revenue stream, but does it guara
componenttext: So staying on the contractual business and the outsourcing since it's becoming so big and important for you all, can you take us inside a little bit and tell us, when you have a multi-year contract, you have a contractual revenue stream, but does it guarantee the level of that revenue stream? Or does that vary and you just know you'll be doing things and getting paid for it? Like how does it work?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's parts of it that are fully guaranteed, Tony, and there's other parts of it that aren't. So we often will have incentives in these contracts that will allow us to earn incremental dollars if we meet certain performance thresholds. And we also will
componenttext: There's parts of it that are fully guaranteed, Tony, and there's other parts of it that aren't. So we often will have incentives in these contracts that will allow us to earn incremental dollars if we meet certain performance thresholds. And we also will have some variable amount of work. So for instance, we may take on a contractual relationship with a big corporate client to do project management work of a certain type for them. And the more projects they do, the more work we do. That's very typical of those accounts. So it's a mixed bag. The way we generally view these big outsourcing accounts when we take them on, they tend -- they're getting larger and larger, so it's not uncommon anymore for us to take on a client and grow it to be a multi-hundred-million dollar revenue source for the company. We almost view these incremental accounts as starting new little businesses within our company. So you start them -- when you start them, there's something there, and then you do a good job and you grow them. And with 90-plus percent renewal rates and increasing customer satisfaction rates, we tend to keep them and grow them. So you end up with something at the core that's largely guaranteed, and you have the opportunity to grow up from there.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then so when you think about the double-digit organic growth in outsourcing, how much of that do you think is winning new contracts and just the expansion and adoption of outsourcing around the world versus, I guess, I don't know, like the same contract revenue concept, if you will?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the CBRE Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Steve Iaco, Investor Relations. Thank you. You may be
componenttext:
Greetings, and welcome to the CBRE Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.
It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Steve Iaco, Investor Relations. Thank you. You may begin.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome to CBRE's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call.Earlier today, we issued a press release announcing our financial results for the quarter and first half of the year. This release is posted on the home page of our website, c
componenttext:
Thank you, and welcome to CBRE's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call.
Earlier today, we issued a press release announcing our financial results for the quarter and first half of the year. This release is posted on the home page of our website, cbre.com. This conference call is being webcast through the Investor Relations section of our website. There, you can find a presentation slide deck, which you can use to follow along with our prepared remarks. An audio archive of the webcast will be posted to the website later today, and a transcript of our call will be posted tomorrow.
Now please turn to slide labeled Forward-looking Statements. This presentation contains statements that are forward-looking within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These include statements regarding CBRE's future growth momentum, operations, market share, business outlook and financial performance expectations. These statements should be considered estimates only, and actual results may ultimately differ from these estimates. Except to the extent required by securities laws, we undertake no obligation to update or publicly revise any forward-looking statements we may make today. For a full discussion of the risks and other factors that may impact any forward-looking statements, please refer to our second quarter earnings report furnished on Form 8-K and our most recent quarterly and annual reports on Form 10-Q and Form 10-K. These results are filed with the SEC and available at sec.gov.
During this presentation, we may make certain statements that are referring to non-GAAP financial measures as defined by SEC regulations. Where required by these regulations, we've provided reconciliations of these measures to what we believe are the most directly comparable GAAP measures. Those reconciliations, together with explanations of these measures, can be found within the appendix of this presentation.
Please turn to Slide 3. Participating on our call today are Bob Sulentic, our President and Chief Executive Officer; Jim Groch, our Chief Financial Officer; and Gil Borok, our Deputy Chief Financial Officer and Chief Accounting Officer.
Now please turn to Slide 4 as I turn the call over to Bob.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve, and good morning, everyone. CBRE posted another quarter of strong growth on the top and bottom lines with a 24% increase in adjusted EPS. This growth came amid an uncertain macro environment and, notably, a time when global property sale
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve, and good morning, everyone. CBRE posted another quarter of strong growth on the top and bottom lines with a 24% increase in adjusted EPS. This growth came amid an uncertain macro environment and, notably, a time when global property sales volumes market-wide have pulled back from a robust 2015. The diversity of CBRE's service offering is especially important in the current market environment. Our performance for the quarter was supported by strong growth in mortgage services, reflecting continued debt capital flows into commercial real estate and in occupier outsourcing, which, once again, grew revenue strongly even before contributions from the acquired Global WorkPlace Solutions business.
Leasing was also up nicely in the Americas and Asia Pacific, and our Investment Management and Development Services businesses produced solid EBITDA gains for the quarter.
Jim will take you through all of this in detail shortly. Before he does, I want to address the UK's vote to leave the European Union.
Please turn to Slide 5. CBRE, like the rest of the commercial real estate services industry, was affected by the high degree of uncertainty in the U.K. market leading up to the referendum on June 23. This can be seen in the nearly 40% drop in U.K. market-wide property sales volumes in Q2, according to CBRE research. However, the effect on CBRE's U.K. revenue was materially less pronounced. In local currency, CBRE's total U.K. fee revenue increased 12%. Without the contributions from the acquired Global WorkPlace Solutions business, U.K. fee revenue in local currency was just 5% below Q2 2015, which had been up 32% over Q2 of the prior year. This performance highlights how significantly our U.K. business has evolved in recent years. During the first half of 2016, occupier outsourcing and property management, which is sticky recurring revenue, accounted for 69% of U.K. fee revenue versus just 19% in the first half of 2013. This shift in our U.K. revenue mix has been driven by our acquisitions of Norland in late 2013 and Global WorkPlace Solutions in September 2015 and positions us well as the U.K. goes about resetting its relationship with the European Union.
Please turn to Slide 6. CBRE expects continued near-term hesitancy among occupiers about space decisions in the U.K., particularly in London. We expect a modest increase in property yields, reflecting the higher perceived risk of holding U.K. property. However, this increase may be temporary, especially for top-tier assets, due to the inherent attractiveness of the U.K. market. In addition, the decline in the value of sterling against the U.S. dollar should provide some incremental support for foreign investments into the U.K. over time. We also anticipate a delay in some office development activity, which should provide longer-term support for property prices as well as rent, particularly in Central London, where availability stands at just 3%.
We are monitoring Brexit-related developments closely. There's a long road ahead, but the swift resolution of the political leadership in Britain is an encouraging sign. Given our clear leadership position, CBRE is well positioned to capitalize on opportunities in the U.K. and across Europe. We are firmly focused on continuing to support our European business and clients.
Now I'll turn the call over to Jim, who will discuss our second quarter results in detail.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. Please turn to Slide 7 for an overview of our financial results. Fee revenue rose 20% in local currency to $2.1 billion or 3% organic growth in fee revenue without the contributions from the acquired Global WorkPlace Solutions business and ot
componenttext:
Thanks, Bob. Please turn to Slide 7 for an overview of our financial results. Fee revenue rose 20% in local currency to $2.1 billion or 3% organic growth in fee revenue without the contributions from the acquired Global WorkPlace Solutions business and other M&A. Adjusted EBITDA for the quarter totaled $360 million, a 19% increase in U.S. dollars from last year's Q2. Margin on fee revenue was 17%. Adjusted earnings per share increased 24% to $0.52 for the quarter. Q2's results include $4 million of net benefit to adjusted EBITDA from currency movement, including gains on hedges. This compares to a net unfavorable impact of $14 million in the second quarter of 2015. Q2 2016 adjusted EBITDA of $360 million includes adjustments for $28 million of integration costs relating to the acquisition of Global WorkPlace Solutions and $27 million incurred in connection with cost elimination program that we discussed in the prior 2 quarters.
Please turn to Slide 8 regarding Q2 results for our 3 regional service segments, all in local currency. Fee revenue increased 18% in the Americas, 31% in EMEA and 18% in Asia Pacific. Without contributions from the acquisition of Global WorkPlace Solutions, fee revenue increased 6% in the Americas and was essentially flat in both EMEA and Asia Pacific.
Please turn to Slide 9 for a review of our business mix. Our business mix continues to evolve towards greater contractual revenue. For the company as a whole, contractual fee revenue was 44% of total fee revenue, up from 34% in Q2 2015 and 19% in Q2 2006.
Please turn to Slide 10 for a review of our major global lines of business in Q2. All percentages increases are in local currency. Occupier outsourcing continued to exhibit strong growth. Global fee revenue was up 118%, aided by the acquisition of Global WorkPlace Solutions. Without contributions from this acquisition, fee revenue rose 10%. Commercial mortgage services had a very good quarter with revenue up 14%, led by private lenders, particularly banks, and continued growth with government-sponsored enterprises. Leasing achieved good growth in the Americas, which was up 8%, and Asia Pacific, which rose 7%. We continue to benefit from the influx of producers choosing to join CBRE.
In the Americas, Canada, Mexico and the U.S. all turned in healthy performances, while Asia Pac was led by Greater China, India and New Zealand. Leasing was down 11% in EMEA as growth in Belgium, Germany and The Netherlands and Spain partially offset a decline in the U.K. Property sales revenue rose 2% in the Americas, while EMEA and Asia Pacific both declined 16%. This compares with an exceptionally strong Q2 2015 when year-on-year growth rates were 25% in the Americas, 62% in EMEA and 24% in Asia Pacific.
Q2 2016 property sales revenue in the U.K. declined by approximately 1/3. CBRE continued to make gains in property sales as evidenced by our 150 basis point market share increase in the U.S. during Q2, according to RCA.
Fee revenue from property management services, which we call asset services, increased by 7%. Valuation revenue was essentially unchanged.
Please turn to Slide 11 regarding our occupier outsourcing business, which we reported within the 3 regional service segments. Finance interest in our outsourcing offering remains high. This can be seen in the 96 total contracts we signed during Q2, including 37 with new clients. Notably, more than 1/3 of these new clients were in EMEA and Asia Pacific. Evidence to the outsourcing is gaining more traction in overseas markets.
Our engagements often span multiple geographies and services. CBRE is well positioned to serve complex, multi-market requirements with our clients with the acquired Global WorkPlace Solutions expertise firmly embedded in our outsourcing business.
Please turn to Slide 12 regarding our Global Investment Management segment. Adjusted EBITDA for this business line increased to $26 million. The business continues to attract significant capital commitments. We raised $1.8 billion of new -- in new equity in Q2 and $7.1 billion in the trailing 12 months. Assets under management totaled $88.6 billion, up $3.9 billion from a year ago in local currency. However, all but $200 million of this increase was offset by foreign currency movement over the past year.
Please turn to Slide 13 regarding our Development Services segment. Strong performance in this business continued in Q2. Adjusted EBITDA totaled $19 million for the quarter, while pro forma revenue, which includes gains on real estate sales, equity earnings and noncontrolling interests, increased to $46 million. These strong results in the quarter were helped by the timing of asset sales. We note that these development asset sales accounting for -- accounted for the vast majority of our equity earnings for the quarter. Due to the timing of project sales, we expect results for the remainder of the year to be heavily weighted to the fourth quarter, with a significantly lighter third quarter. Development projects in process totaled $7.1 billion, up $1.1 billion from Q2 2015. The pipeline of $3 billion was down $700 million from a year ago as projects converted from pipeline to in-process.
Please turn to Slide 14. Before I turn the call back to Bob, I'd like to briefly highlight our results for the first half of 2016. These results are strong, including growth rates of 24% in fee revenue in local currency, 17% in adjusted EBITDA and 21% in adjusted earnings per share. This growth is particularly notable coming at a time when average earnings of S&P 500 companies are expected to decline in Q2 2016 for the fifth consecutive quarter.
Please turn to Slide 15 for Bob's closing remarks.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. As you've seen, our business has performed very well in the first half of 2016, even with a decline in market-wide property sales volumes compared to a year ago. It is important to note that market fundamentals in commercial real estate remai
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim. As you've seen, our business has performed very well in the first half of 2016, even with a decline in market-wide property sales volumes compared to a year ago. It is important to note that market fundamentals in commercial real estate remain in good shape, with the impact of Brexit largely limited to property transactions activity in the U.K., and we anticipate solid earnings growth for the year. Looking ahead, we are adjusting our outlook for the remainder of the year. This is due principally to the impact of Brexit on U.K. property transaction volumes and less visibility around the timing of the realization of certain tenants in our Global Investment Management business and Development Services business. These factors have caused us to reduce our earnings guidance by 3% at the top end of our range and by 5% at the bottom end. This results in expected adjusted EPS for the calendar year of $2.15 to $2.30, which represents solid growth of approximately 9% at the midpoint of the range. We see adjusted EPS in the second half of 2016 more weighted to Q4 rather than Q3 compared with our customary progression of earnings throughout the year.
As the clear market leader, CBRE is well positioned to further extend our competitive advantage in the marketplace. Our ongoing talent and technology initiatives, collaborative culture, market-leading service offering and financial strength uniquely position us to satisfy clients' growing demand for our services.
With that, operator, we'll open the lines for questions.

componenttext: Wanted to ask about the guidance. The initial guidance you gave us for the year indicated that leasing was going to grow high single digits; capital markets, mid- to high single digits; outsourcing, low double digits; and your principal business EBITDA will be flat to slightly down. So the updated guidance that you're giving us today, can you give us an update on how those expectations have changed as they're reflected in the full year guidance?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Jim, sure. Yes, we're not changing any to specific guidance that we gave early in the year and actually think that generally, we still anticipate all those ranges that we gave that will perform within the ranges provided at the beginning of the year.
componenttext: It's Jim, sure. Yes, we're not changing any to specific guidance that we gave early in the year and actually think that generally, we still anticipate all those ranges that we gave that will perform within the ranges provided at the beginning of the year. If you look at the update on our guidance at the midpoint, it's -- the range is a little wider, and at the midpoint, we're down 4%. And I think as we kind of referenced, a little more than half of that is really tied to Brexit impact on U.K. transactions. And then some of the widening and a bit that's left is in there around just some timing risk around the realization of incentives in our Global Investment Management and Development Services and then just some very minor tweaks to our forecast internally.

componenttext: Okay. And staying with the U.K., Slide 5, I appreciate the detail on the U.K. business. Can you give us a sense of the exposure that you have within your principal businesses? While I assume there's not much for Development Services, but interested in Investment Management exposure.

componenttext: Okay. headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of sales and leasing, it seems like you guys had another quarter of share gains, at least relative to the third-party data. Can you talk about whether you think that's happening from more wins or this is headcount? Or what do you think is driving
componenttext: In terms of sales and leasing, it seems like you guys had another quarter of share gains, at least relative to the third-party data. Can you talk about whether you think that's happening from more wins or this is headcount? Or what do you think is driving that?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tony, this is Bob. Headcount is certainly part of it. We've talked over the last several quarters about the gains we've made over the last 2 to 3 years in recruiting. That has continued into this year, although at a slower pace, partially because some of
componenttext: Tony, this is Bob. Headcount is certainly part of it. We've talked over the last several quarters about the gains we've made over the last 2 to 3 years in recruiting. That has continued into this year, although at a slower pace, partially because some of the pricing we've seen out there for recruiting we don't think makes sense. So our recruiting is down by about 1/3 this year. The other thing that's benefiting us is some of the strategic things we've done with those businesses. And notably, we've grown our small asset class business materially on the sales side. And on the advisory and transaction services side of our occupier client offering, we've integrated our outsourcing business with our local brokerage business and added a bunch of advisory capabilities that have really allowed us to take on a lot of account business beyond what we were ever able to do before and offer things to our clients that go beyond what we were able to offer before. And that's coming through on our numbers, and it's coming through on our numbers for outsourcing business and our local brokerage business or local leasing business, and we're taking market share as a result.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And can you help us at all with thinking about just the incremental margins for sales and leasing as we kind of look ahead?

componenttext: Okay. Then if I look at your cost elimination program, you guys spent, I think, $27 million on this in the second quarter, and that was up from about $8 million or $9 million, I think, in the first quarter. How much do you think you're going to drive in terms of run rate savings from the initiative? Like how much is left here because it seems like it's been extended since last quarter?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We haven't given specific guidance on where that's going. I would say, we mentioned that we started this program late last year. And at the time, we noted that just we've grown the business massively over the last 3 years. And when you do, intermittently
componenttext: We haven't given specific guidance on where that's going. I would say, we mentioned that we started this program late last year. And at the time, we noted that just we've grown the business massively over the last 3 years. And when you do, intermittently you need to step back and look for pockets where you may have some inefficiency. And then we thought that it was a good time to kind of work on that. But I'd also highlight that all those savings don't drop to the bottom line because we do reinvest. While we're cutting costs in some areas, we are looking to reinvest in other areas where we think we'll get real leverage from our investments.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Yes, Tony, Brexit hasn't really impacted the growth of that business or the stability of that business. And we did achieve 13% organic growth in that business in the first half, very consistent with our expectations for the business, which are unchanged in terms of the ongoing organic growth. We're extremely pleased with the way that business has grown year-to-date. By the way, it was double-digit growth in the second quarter, too, at 10%. There's a little inefficiency quarter-to-quarter. And we're quite excited about what we think the profile from continued growth of that business is.

componenttext: Regarding the guidance and your comments about weighting more toward 4Q than 3Q relative to historical performance, can you maybe put some color around what the drivers of that are? Is that due to increased uncertainty in 3Q around capital markets volumes that you expect to normalize in the fourth quarter? Or is it those incentive fee realizations?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there's nothing particularly driving it, really just the timing of whether it's carried interest in the Investment Management business or individual sales within the Development Services business. It can differ from year-to-year, from quarter-to-quar
componenttext: Yes, there's nothing particularly driving it, really just the timing of whether it's carried interest in the Investment Management business or individual sales within the Development Services business. It can differ from year-to-year, from quarter-to-quarter. We're ahead on activity year-to-date versus last year, and we just look at the timing on these when we see transactions coming in Q3 looks like it'll be light and Q4 looks like it will be strong. Although in comparison, the last year, Q4 was exceptionally strong. So we don't -- with Q4 at that type of activity will likely be down from Q4 of last year still. So Q3 will be light and just timing. Some deals we thought we were going to hit in Q3 happened in Q2 and looked like some others are actually going to hit in Q4 instead of 3.
