headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to CBRE Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to your host, Steve Iaco with Investor Relations. Mr. Iaco, you may
componenttext: Greetings, and welcome to CBRE Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to your host, Steve Iaco with Investor Relations. Mr. Iaco, you may begin.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome to CBRE's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call.Earlier today, we issued a press release announcing our financial results for the quarter and the first 9 months of the year. This release is posted on the home page of our web
componenttext:
Thank you, and welcome to CBRE's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call.
Earlier today, we issued a press release announcing our financial results for the quarter and the first 9 months of the year. This release is posted on the home page of our website, cbre.com.
This conference call is being webcast through the Investor Relations section of our website. There, you can also find a presentation slide deck, which you can use to follow along with our prepared remarks. An audio archive of the webcast will be posted to the website later today, and a transcript of our call will be posted tomorrow. Now please turn to slide labeled Forward-looking Statements. This presentation contains statements that are forward-looking within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These include statements regarding CBRE's future growth momentum, operations, market share, business outlook and financial performance expectations. These statements should be considered estimates only, and actual results may ultimately differ from these estimates. Except to the extent required by securities laws, we undertake no obligation to update or publicly revise any forward-looking statements we may make today. For a full discussion of the risks and other factors that may impact any forward-looking statements, please refer to our third quarter 2016 earnings report furnished on Form 8-K and our most recent quarterly and annual reports on Form 10-Q and 10-K. These reports are filed with the SEC and available at sec.gov. During this presentation, we may make certain statements that refer to non-GAAP financial measures as defined by SEC regulations. Where required by these regulations, we have provided reconciliations of these measures to what we believe are the most directly comparable GAAP measures. Those reconciliations, together with explanations of these measures, can be found within the appendix of this presentation. Please turn to Slide 3. 
Participating on our call today are Bob Sulentic, our President and Chief Executive Officer; Jim Groch, our Chief Financial Officer; and Gil Borok, our Deputy Chief Financial Officer and Chief Accounting Officer. 
Now please turn to Slide 4 as I turn the call over to Bob.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve, and good morning, everyone. By now, you've read our press release detailing CBRE's financial results for the third quarter of 2016, which Jim will discuss shortly. Our results are solid and largely in line with our, and the markets', e
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve, and good morning, everyone. By now, you've read our press release detailing CBRE's financial results for the third quarter of 2016, which Jim will discuss shortly. 
Our results are solid and largely in line with our, and the markets', expectations. Our performance is notable when viewed against the exceptionally strong growth we posted in last year's Q3 and a backdrop of lower property sales volumes in most markets. In this environment, CBRE's premier position in commercial real estate with a deep, diverse market-leading service offering continues to serve us and our clients well. 
Occupier outsourcing, our largest business line, saw fee revenue growth of 16% or better in local currency in each of our 3 regions before contributions from the acquired Global Workplace Solutions business. This acquisition, which we completed 13 months ago, has fortified our capabilities and given us an advantage position serving occupier clients. The diversity and depth of our service offering helps set CBRE apart from others in our sector. 
Another way we're distinguishing ourselves is through the strategic gains we're making across the company. Our investments in people, digital initiatives, specialized consulting services and other capabilities are driving growth and enhancing CBRE's ability to deliver highly differentiated client outcomes. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Jim for a detailed review of our third quarter results.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. Please turn to Slide 5 for an overview of our financial results. As Bob noted, Q3 was a solid quarter against an exceptionally strong Q3 of 2015. To put this into perspective, we achieved growth rates in Q3 2015 of 21% in fee revenue and 24%
componenttext:
Thanks, Bob. Please turn to Slide 5 for an overview of our financial results. As Bob noted, Q3 was a solid quarter against an exceptionally strong Q3 of 2015. To put this into perspective, we achieved growth rates in Q3 2015 of 21% in fee revenue and 24% in adjusted EBITDA, both in local currency, and 28% in adjusted EPS. 
In Q3 of 2016, fee revenue of $2.1 billion was up 11% in local currency from Q3 2015. Organic growth without the contributions from acquisitions, including the Global Workplace Solutions business, increased 1%. 
Adjusted EBITDA for the quarter totaled $349 million, a 1% increase in U.S. dollars from last year's Q3 or 5% increase without the impact of currency movements, including hedging. Adjusted EBITDA margin on fee revenue for the quarter was solid at 16.5% despite headwinds versus prior year Q3 from reduced carried interest, decreased property sales and increased cost to retain and attract talent. 
Adjusted earnings per share totaled $0.50 for the quarter. 
Comparing Q3 2016 results for the year earlier quarter, currency movement, including hedges, had a negative impact of $12.9 million to adjusted EBITDA and $0.03 to adjusted EPS. Without this impact, adjusted EPS was up 4%. 
Q3 2016 adjusted EBITDA of $349 million includes $38.9 million incurred in connection with the cost elimination program that we discussed in the prior 3 quarters. This program is now complete. It also includes $28.6 million of integration costs relating to the acquisition of Global Workplace Solutions. 
In Q3, we continue to maintain our investment discipline around M&A as we have seen pricing increase on less stable income streams during 2016. We remain actively engaged in the market but are willing to step aside when price or terms are out of step with our underwriting criteria. 
In a similar vein, recruiting in the sales and leasing businesses continued at a measured pace. As noted on prior calls, we have tightened underwriting and reduced our net recruiting significantly versus the pace of the last few years. Nonetheless, we expect to add hundreds of producers, net of departures this year, while maintaining by far the highest EBITDA margins among the diversified services providers. 
Please turn to Slide 6, regarding Q3 results for our 3 regional services segments, all on local currency. Fee revenue increased 25% in EMEA and 9% in both the Americas and Asia Pacific. Without contributions from the acquisition of Global Workplace Solutions, fee revenue increased 8% in EMEA and 3% in the Americas, but declined 2% in Asia Pacific. After removing the effect of foreign currency, including hedging in both Q3 '16 and 2015, adjusted EBITDA increased 19% in EMEA and 6% in the Americas, while decreasing 8% in Asia Pacific. 
Our strong performance in EMEA this quarter highlights the steps we have taken in recent years to strengthen our position. A material slowdown in transaction activity in the U.K., our largest market in the region, was more than offset by the results from 3 areas of focus: Number one, significant growth in our outsourcing business; two, the strength of our business in Continental Europe, which is benefiting from an enhanced leadership team; and three, run rate operating savings from our proactive cost elimination program, which began a year ago and is now complete. 
In the U.K., overall gross revenue and fee revenue grew 20% and 12%, respectively, or 8% and 2%, excluding the acquired Global Workplace Solutions business. This growth occurred despite the slowdown in the U.K. transaction market in the wake of Brexit. 
Please turn to Slide 7 for a review of our business mix. The company's business mix has evolved significantly in recent years. Contractual fee revenue comprised 42% of total fee revenue for the company as a whole. This compares with 37% in Q3 2015 and 20% in Q3 2006. 
Please turn to Slide 8 for a review of our major global lines of business. In Q3, all percentage increases are in local currency. As Bob mentioned, occupier outsourcing indeed a very strong growth. Organic fee revenue rose 19% without the contributions from the acquired Global Workplace Solutions accounts. Strength was exhibited around the world with fee revenue growth rates, ex the Global Workforce Global Workplace Solutions acquisition of 16% in the Americas, 21% in EMEA and 25% in Asia Pacific. 
Property sales activity was healthy by historical standards, but global sales revenue declined 7% compared with a very strong Q3 2015 when our global sales revenue rose 19%. 
In Q3 2016, EMEA saw strong growth in France, The Netherlands and Switzerland, which offset continued weakness in property sales in the U.K. in the wake of Brexit. 
Commercial mortgage services rose 24% driven by gains from mortgage servicing rights and increased loan originations for the government-sponsored enterprises to provide financing to multifamily assets. 
Year-to-date, capital markets revenues were up 2%. In light of lower sales revenue in Q3 and the impact of Brexit discussed last quarter, we now expect our capital markets revenues to be flat to slightly up for the year. 
Leasing revenue grew 2% in Q3 compared with largely flat global market volumes and a very strong Q3 for CBRE in 2015, which saw leasing up 12% globally. Year-to-date, our leasing revenues are up 7% globally. 
In the Americas, robust growth in Brazil, Canada and Mexico offset flat performance in the U.S. in Q3. Year-to-date leasing revenue in the Americas has increased 9%. In Asia Pacific, leasing revenue increased 4% in Q3, led by Greater China, Japan and Singapore. Leasing in EMEA rose 3%, a turnaround from a decline in Q2. A number of countries showed strength notably France, Ireland, Poland and Switzerland. 
Fee revenue from property management services increased by 2%. Valuation revenue was essentially unchanged for the quarter. 
Please turn to Slide 9 regarding our occupier outsourcing business, which is reported within the 3 regional service segments. This business' ongoing appeal to large space users can be seen in the 113 total outsourcing contracts, including facility management, project management and transaction management signed during Q3, including 52 expansions of client -- existing client relationships, a company record. 
In our outsourcing business, gross revenue, as determined under GAAP, depends on the contracts structure while there's typically no impact on the calculation of fee revenue. As we harmonize contract structures and renewals of legacy JCI Global Workplace Solutions clients, we will likely continue to experience different growth rates over time for gross and fee revenue. We believe fee revenue generally provide a more consistent view of revenue growth. 
We continue to make great inroads in the health care sector, an underpenetrated market with significant growth potential. We signed 16 total contracts in this sector in Q3 adding new clients like [indiscernible] hospital and Mount Sinai Health System, while expanding our work for existing clients such as Johns Hopkins. 
We're also well positioned to capture integrated multiservice, multi-geography mandates. One recent example was ExxonMobile [ph] which selected CBRE to provide integrated facilities, project and transaction management services throughout Asia Pacific and the Americas. 
CBRE's capabilities enable us to create competitive advantage for our global clients and in turn, drive growth opportunities in our outsourcing and the transaction businesses. 
Please turn to Slide 10 regarding our Global Investment Management segment. Adjusted EBITDA for this business totaled $19 million, down from a particularly strong Q3 of 2015. This decrease was driven by the timing of carried interest. Just $2 million of carried interest revenue was realized in the current quarter compared with $19 million in the prior year period. 
Attesting to the strong returns this business line generates for its clients, total equity commitments in Q3 rose to $2.1 billion, the highest level in 9 quarters. Total equity raised over the past 12 months increased to $7.4 billion. 
Assets under management totaled $87.9 billion, up $5 billion from a year ago in local currency. Foreign currency movement over the past year limited the increase to $1.9 billion in U.S. dollars. This reflects the fact that approximately 60% of our AUM, excluding securities, is in Europe and is generally denominated in euros and pounds sterling. 
Please turn to Slide 11 regarding our Development Services segment. This business continue to perform well. Adjusted EBITDA totaled nearly $16 million for Q3, while pro forma revenue, which includes gains on real estate sales, equity earnings and noncontrolling interests increased to $43 million. Development projects in process totaled $7.1 billion, up $400 million from Q3 2015. 
The new projects pipeline totaled $3.7 billion, down $300 million from a year ago as projects have converted from pipeline to in-process. 
Now looking at our Development Services and investment segments together. As noted in the last quarter, we continue to see some uncertainty as to the timing of the realization of incentives. 
Please turn to Slide 12. Before I turn the call back to Bob, I'd like to briefly highlight our results for the first 9 months of 2016. Fee revenue increased 19% and adjusted EBITDA rose 12%, both in local currency. Adjusted earnings per share increased 10% or 13% without the effects of currency changes, including hedging. This strong performance was on top of an exceptional growth for the first 9 months of 2015 when we achieved growth rates of 24% for adjusted EBITDA and 30% per adjusted EPS, both without the effects of currency, including hedging. 
Now please turn to Slide 13 for Bob's closing remarks.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim. CBRE has continued to produce strong results for our shareholders as we invest in our people and platform, including digital initiatives to drive long-term growth and create superior outcomes for our clients. Commercial real estate fundame
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim. CBRE has continued to produce strong results for our shareholders as we invest in our people and platform, including digital initiatives to drive long-term growth and create superior outcomes for our clients. Commercial real estate fundamentals remain healthy in most parts of the world and the global economy continues to grow at a modest pace. CBRE as the clear market leader is well positioned to achieve strong long-term financial performance and widen our competitive advantage in the marketplace. 
We continue to expect adjusted EPS for the full year of $2.15 to $2.30, which represents solid growth of approximately 9% at the midpoint of the range on top of an exceptional performance in 2015. 
Before we close, you'll note that this morning, we announced an authorization to repurchase up to $250 million of our shares over the next 3 years. The strength of our balance sheet, considerable cash flow and resiliency of our business gives us the flexibility to return capital to our shareholders, while continuing to meet long-term growth-oriented investments. 
With that, operator, we'll open the line for questions.

But also just some timing around carried interest, which we also noted.

componenttext: Okay. componenttext: Tony, this is Jim. I guess, I would just comment overall on the margins. Our margin for the quarter was 16.5%. Our margin year-to-date is 16.4%. The margins are only down modestly and basically back to where they were a little over a year ago. So we've given back some of the operating leverage that we picked up last year. But the margins I think, it held up pretty nicely, especially after the acquisition of GWS and after the fact the sales have been down this year.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tony, this is Bob. There is a decent amount of that going on in the market. The articles that are out there get somethings right and miss something in a pretty big way. But we very much maintained our discipline around underwriting before retaining and re
componenttext: Tony, this is Bob. There is a decent amount of that going on in the market. The articles that are out there get somethings right and miss something in a pretty big way. But we very much maintained our discipline around underwriting before retaining and recruiting brokerage talent. And as a result, our recruiting this year, while very active, is down meaningfully from the record kind of pace we had the last couple of years. We expect to add several hundred brokers, but it'll be off meaningfully from where it's been. And we simply aren't going to participate in what we consider to be irrational pricing in the recruiting world.

componenttext: On the property sales business, looking beyond the fourth quarter, can you just give us some color on what trend you're seeing in the market, for example, how bid list on transactions look? Are you seeing fewer participants? Are you seeing increased caution on underwriting? Or do you think that there's kind of an underlying resiliency in the marketplace and perhaps may be the U.S. election is a factor weighing on sales pace?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jade this is Jim. We are seeing, in our system, where we track a number of folks that are signing nondisclosure agreements per deal, that's remained pretty steady and at a high number kind of in the upper 50s per deal of people that have seen it, reviewed
componenttext: Jade this is Jim. We are seeing, in our system, where we track a number of folks that are signing nondisclosure agreements per deal, that's remained pretty steady and at a high number kind of in the upper 50s per deal of people that have seen it, reviewed the teaser and come in and signed the full nondisclosure agreements, so there's interest. That's held pretty steady. We have seen days on the market increase a bit, may be 10% or so. So we have a seen a little more caution as the year played out.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just on the leasing business, can you comment on the flat performance in the U.S., and maybe differentiate between the gateway cities versus secondary markets? What do you think is driving the flattish performance, is it supply or any changes in lea
componenttext: Okay. Just on the leasing business, can you comment on the flat performance in the U.S., and maybe differentiate between the gateway cities versus secondary markets? What do you think is driving the flattish performance, is it supply or any changes in leasing velocity?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Supply comes into play once in a while in a few markets but it's not if primary driver. First of all, it's important to note that the flatness is one quarter. Year-to-date, we've had good growth. And secondly, there is a little uncertainty out there among
componenttext: Supply comes into play once in a while in a few markets but it's not if primary driver. First of all, it's important to note that the flatness is one quarter. Year-to-date, we've had good growth. And secondly, there is a little uncertainty out there among occupiers as to what they want to do. We're also comparing against a really strongly year from last year. So I think it's hard to read too much into what happened over the last 90 days. And we still expect to see growth in the economy, we still expect to see healthy leasing activity. But keep in mind, the backdrop of a little uncertainty and a very strong compare from year ago.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the M&A side, we get lots of questions about sort of the rationale behind the various M&A transactions that the major brokers have pursued. Can you give some color on how you're thinking about M&A? And also, what benchmarks you look at, for example, ho
componenttext: On the M&A side, we get lots of questions about sort of the rationale behind the various M&A transactions that the major brokers have pursued. Can you give some color on how you're thinking about M&A? And also, what benchmarks you look at, for example, how do you think about return on invested capital?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We don't give very specific underwriting things we've noted in the past is that the infill M&A for us is historically continued on average to 5 to 6x EBITDA range. We note that our cost of capital we believe is in the plus or minus 10% range, and th
componenttext: Sure. We don't give very specific underwriting things we've noted in the past is that the infill M&A for us is historically continued on average to 5 to 6x EBITDA range. We note that our cost of capital we believe is in the plus or minus 10% range, and that we conservatively underwrite well in excess of that kind of a return on an IRR basis. So that gives you a couple of metrics to have a sense for. And we've commented throughout the last year but really the last, I would say, 12 to 18 months, we've seen the deal flow relatively strong opportunities are out there. But we have felt that pricing was getting heady and that the income streams that are being priced were less certain. And as a result, we've pulled back on deal volume that we've been closing, we've stepped away from deals where we had to latch out to make the deal, we just didn't think the economic returns -- the risk reward ratio was right. So hopefully that gives you some feedback there.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Yes. And just finally, on the MS our gains, can you quantify may be on a per share impact, that MSR gains contributed to adjusted EPS?

componenttext: We don't quantify in total. What I could tell you is on an EBITDA basis, the incremental in this quarter versus the same quarter last year was $26.5 million.

componenttextpreview: Yes, David. This is Bob. That is a very important part of our strategy. We have the put in place an initiative we call advisory and transaction services for occupiers. It operates at the intersection between our occupier brokerage or tenant rent businesse
componenttext: Yes, David. This is Bob. That is a very important part of our strategy. We have the put in place an initiative we call advisory and transaction services for occupiers. It operates at the intersection between our occupier brokerage or tenant rent businesses a lot of people call it in our transaction management business for our large occupier outsourcing accounts. We've added a lot of consultative capability and data capability to that offering. And we're seeing a very good results, and we're counting on those results to be a big part of the future of that business.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then has that financing become incrementally more difficult to obtain for potential buyers on the capital market side? And are you seeing that as a potential tailwind for your commercial mortgage brokerage business?

componenttextpreview: Well, our commercial of brokerage business, there's a lot of work with the GSEs, and that is very active and we expect that to continue to be very active through the course of the year, much more skewed in that direction, multifamily, than our sales busin
componenttext: Well, our commercial of brokerage business, there's a lot of work with the GSEs, and that is very active and we expect that to continue to be very active through the course of the year, much more skewed in that direction, multifamily, than our sales businesses, and that's why you've seen a divergence in the volume of our mortgage origination business and the volume of our sales business. We expect there to be adequate capital from the life companies and GSE is going forward. So we expect to see strong volume for the balance of the year.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and I know you're not giving quantification -- on the cost illumination program, but may be could you -- have we seen half the benefit of the full run rate of this program in the third quarter? Was it -- do we see most of the full run rate benefit i
componenttext: Okay, and I know you're not giving quantification -- on the cost illumination program, but may be could you -- have we seen half the benefit of the full run rate of this program in the third quarter? Was it -- do we see most of the full run rate benefit in the third quarter? Is there some color you can give us around that?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it continued through 3 quarters and, of course, you don't get the run rate on -- you certainly don't get the full years worth of run rate on anything you did after the first quarter of the year. So we expect -- we will receive meaningful benefit of
componenttext: Well, it continued through 3 quarters and, of course, you don't get the run rate on -- you certainly don't get the full years worth of run rate on anything you did after the first quarter of the year. So we expect -- we will receive meaningful benefit of this year. We'll receive more benefit from it next year. But we're really aren't quantifying it on an annual or quarterly basis. It was an important and significant program though.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from the line of Brandon Dobell from William Blair.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Brandon Dobell from William Blair.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: May be either Bob or Jim, some comments about the leasing market momentum if you compare how things feel here in North America versus Europe. And has there been any I wouldn't call it snapback but any recovery and momentum now we've got a bit of distance
componenttext: May be either Bob or Jim, some comments about the leasing market momentum if you compare how things feel here in North America versus Europe. And has there been any I wouldn't call it snapback but any recovery and momentum now we've got a bit of distance after the Brexit vote?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, leasing volume was down significantly in the U.K. but on Continental Europe, it's doing much better, and we meaningfully outperformed the market on Continental Europe. We think the volume in the U.K. was down in the mid-double digits. We were down f
componenttext: Well, leasing volume was down significantly in the U.K. but on Continental Europe, it's doing much better, and we meaningfully outperformed the market on Continental Europe. We think the volume in the U.K. was down in the mid-double digits. We were down far less than that. We grew very dramatically on the continent as a result of some of the things that Jim talked about in his prepared remarks. I would say, around the world, it's kind of what I said earlier, Brandon, there's significant activity. But against the backdrop from last year, where we and the market grew dramatically, it seems fairly muted. We expect there to continue to be solid activity. We expect the market there to be job growth kind of like the job growth we had so far this year. But there is uncertainty in the marketplace, which is putting pressure on the results relative to what they were a year ago.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thinking about your transaction producers and how this works. But given the strength the past couple of years and it sounds like there's a reasonably competitive market for, especially the top people these days, are you already talking with you guys
componenttext: Okay. Thinking about your transaction producers and how this works. But given the strength the past couple of years and it sounds like there's a reasonably competitive market for, especially the top people these days, are you already talking with you guys about who split structures, those kinds of things, are going to look for next year going into year end? Or may be asked a different way, do you think the producers have a little more leverage going in the year end or thinking about '17 than they would have for the past couple of years?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The way we run the business, we try to have a platform, a set of capabilities, a brand, a client base that allows us to pursue our policies on a consistent kind of long-term basis. We, for instance, we do work with virtually every major corporation in the
componenttext: The way we run the business, we try to have a platform, a set of capabilities, a brand, a client base that allows us to pursue our policies on a consistent kind of long-term basis. We, for instance, we do work with virtually every major corporation in the world. We have a $90 billion AUM Investment Management business that we do a lot of work for. We have $7 billion of development in process that virtually all of which is leased and sold by our brokers. As Jim's noted a number of the times, we get about 1/3 of our occupier leasing work from our base of outsourcing clients. And we increasingly invest in technology and consultative capability to support our brokers. we're not going from quarter-to-quarter in from poaching headline to poaching headline and adjusting the way we engage with our brokers on a financial basis. It's much more of a long-term plan.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And final one for me to think about Investment Management business. The type of capital you're raising from the various sources, may be some color around what the fee structures look like, how sticky the capital may be in terms of what those deals l
componenttext: Okay. And final one for me to think about Investment Management business. The type of capital you're raising from the various sources, may be some color around what the fee structures look like, how sticky the capital may be in terms of what those deals look like versus last year, a couple years ago, I guess I'm just trying to get a sense for whether you're thing things in the capital raised within CBRE that gives you a little either pause, some cause for concerns or gives you different feel for where your cost may think on the cycle versus a brokers transaction customer might?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I would say, with regard to fees in the business, we had fees in Europe, particularly continental fee pressure in Europe, virtually Continental Europe, for part of the last few years. We're really not seeing too much of that anymore. I think that st
componenttext: Sure. I would say, with regard to fees in the business, we had fees in Europe, particularly continental fee pressure in Europe, virtually Continental Europe, for part of the last few years. We're really not seeing too much of that anymore. I think that stabilized. We are a core base. Our platform is primarily targeting investment of core properties. We do have value add funds that are Bayer high performance, but the majority of our AUM is core plus, product tends to be pretty stable and stable fee structures. Sometimes, we'll have an impact on mix, we can have mix changed a bit, particularly in Europe where folks are coming out of higher fee funds and moving more into separate accounts where they wanted more control or core, core plus that had a lower fee structure. But generally, I think we're seeing that to be reasonably stable today.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Alan Lyle [ph] with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Alan Lyle [ph] with Goldman Sachs.

componenttext: Just one for me. You touched on fewer attractive opportunities to deploy capital into M&A. I was wondering how much of professional for the buyback due to attractiveness of your current share price? And how much of it is due to fewer opportunities to deploy capital for your acquisitions?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, we try not to comment generally on our share price. I would say, the fact that we've had a slower pace over the last 18 months was helpful and as we think about our capital allocation opportunities to give us more comfort that we can do both in buil
componenttext: Sure, we try not to comment generally on our share price. I would say, the fact that we've had a slower pace over the last 18 months was helpful and as we think about our capital allocation opportunities to give us more comfort that we can do both in building up a little bit of liquidity. But the other factor I would comment on is just the growth in the company over the last few years, our profitability is up considerably and the flexibility we have on our balance sheet really gives us comfort that we can do both. The other thing I'd just reiterate, the opportunities to other colleges the pricing is often that doesn't usually last forever so [indiscernible] we'll see more in the future.

componenttext: So just another question on the cost elimination program. In kind of you're saying that it's over, is that kind of capturing where your outlook is for the global economy and the industry and where we're heading, is that kind of captured into your thoughts? Or if we have a leg down, is there potential reemergence in this cost elimination program?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mitch, we always focus on cost. We think it's a strategic initiative for us because we have very much committed to continuing to invest in our strategy through cycle, it was tough to do that in past cycles. That's something that we've addressed where spec
componenttext: Mitch, we always focus on cost. We think it's a strategic initiative for us because we have very much committed to continuing to invest in our strategy through cycle, it was tough to do that in past cycles. That's something that we've addressed where specifically. And so we're focused on cost. We decided a year or so ago that after, by the time 6-plus years of strong growth when we are adding all kinds of people and capability, that it was time to kind of scrutinize what we have done and formally address some cost inefficiencies. That was what drove that initiative. It wasn't looking at the market or predicting where the market cycle was going. We completed that program. But we will remain very, very focused on cost management. And if we think we're at a point in time any where we're just getting too much cost or cost at the wrong type or we've made investments that we need to pull back on, then we'll get more aggressive. But the formal program has been completed.

componenttext: Yes. We think that our leaders in the U.K. tell us that they believe that there is a reasonable chance that activity will pick up now. componenttextpreview: I think the customers respond to capabilities. And if you look back 2, 2-plus years ago, before we did Morland, our critical mass of self execution capability was primarily in the U.S. In Norland, we picked up considerable critical mass in the U.K. and wi
componenttext: I think the customers respond to capabilities. And if you look back 2, 2-plus years ago, before we did Morland, our critical mass of self execution capability was primarily in the U.S. In Norland, we picked up considerable critical mass in the U.K. and with GWS, we picked up critical mass and capabilities throughout most of the world. And I think we're seeing response to that, which is more capable we are, the more clients would like to give us more work to do and work with 1 or 2 or 3 max providers.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome to CBRE's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call.Earlier today, we issued a press release announcing our financial results for the quarter and the first 9 months of the year. This release is posted on the home page of our web
componenttext:
Thank you, and welcome to CBRE's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call.
Earlier today, we issued a press release announcing our financial results for the quarter and the first 9 months of the year. This release is posted on the home page of our website, cbre.com.
This conference call is being webcast through the Investor Relations section of our website. There, you can also find a presentation slide deck, which you can use to follow along with our prepared remarks. An audio archive of the webcast will be posted to the website later today, and a transcript of our call will be posted tomorrow. 
Now please turn to slide labeled Forward-looking Statements. This presentation contains statements that are forward-looking within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These include statements regarding CBRE's future growth momentum, operations, market share, business outlook and financial performance expectations. These statements should be considered estimates only, and actual results may ultimately differ from these estimates. Except to the extent required by securities laws, we undertake no obligation to update or publicly revise any forward-looking statements we may make today. For a full discussion of the risks and other factors that may impact any forward-looking statements, please refer to our third quarter 2016 earnings report furnished on Form 8-K and our most recent quarterly and annual reports on Form 10-Q and 10-K. These reports are filed with the SEC and are available at sec.gov. 
During this presentation, we may make certain statements that refer to non-GAAP financial measures as defined by SEC regulations. Where required by these regulations, we have provided reconciliations of these measures to what we believe are the most directly comparable GAAP measures. Those reconciliations, together with explanations of these measures, can be found within the appendix of this presentation. 
Please turn to Slide 3. Participating on our call today are Bob Sulentic, our President and Chief Executive Officer; Jim Groch, our Chief Financial Officer; and Gil Borok, our Deputy Chief Financial Officer and Chief Accounting Officer. 
Now please turn to Slide 4 as I turn the call over to Bob.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve, and good morning, everyone. By now you've read our press release detailing CBRE's financial results for the third quarter of 2016, which Jim will discuss shortly. Our results are solid and largely in line with our and the markets' expe
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve, and good morning, everyone. By now you've read our press release detailing CBRE's financial results for the third quarter of 2016, which Jim will discuss shortly. 
Our results are solid and largely in line with our and the markets' expectations. Our performance is notable when viewed against the exceptionally strong growth we posted in last year's Q3 and a backdrop of lower property sales volumes in most markets. In this environment, CBRE's premier position in commercial real estate with a deep, diverse market-leading service offering continues to serve us and our clients well. Occupier outsourcing, our largest business line, saw a fee revenue growth of 16% or better in local currency in each of our 3 regions before contributions from the acquired Global Workplace Solutions business. This acquisition, which we competed -- completed 13 months ago, has fortified our capabilities and given us an advantaged position serving occupier clients. The diversity and depth of our service offering helps set CBRE apart from others in our sector. 
Another way we're distinguishing ourselves is through the strategic gains we're making across the company. Our investments in people, digital initiatives, specialized consulting services and other capabilities are driving growth and enhancing CBRE's ability to deliver highly differentiated client outcomes. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Jim for a detailed review of our third quarter results.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. Please turn to Slide 5 for an overview of our financial results. As Bob noted, Q3 was a solid quarter against an exceptionally strong Q3 of 2015. To put this into perspective, we achieved growth rates in Q3 2015 of 21% in fee revenue and 24%
componenttext:
Thanks, Bob. Please turn to Slide 5 for an overview of our financial results. As Bob noted, Q3 was a solid quarter against an exceptionally strong Q3 of 2015. To put this into perspective, we achieved growth rates in Q3 2015 of 21% in fee revenue and 24% in adjusted EBITDA, both on local currency, and 28% in adjusted EPS. 
In Q3 of 2016, fee revenue of $2.1 billion was up 11% in local currency from Q3 2015. Organic growth without the contributions from acquisitions, including the Global Workplace Solutions business, increased 1%. Adjusted EBITDA for the quarter totaled $349 million, a 1% increase in U.S. dollars from last year's Q3 or 5% increase without the impact of currency movements, including hedging. Adjusted EBITDA margin on fee revenue for the quarter was solid at 16.5% despite headwinds versus prior year Q3 from reduced carried interest, decreased property sales and increased cost to retain and attract talent. Adjusted earnings per share totaled $0.50 for the quarter. 
Comparing Q3 2016 results for the year-earlier quarter, currency movement, including hedges, had a negative impact of $12.9 million to adjusted EBITDA and $0.03 to adjusted EPS. Without this impact, adjusted EPS was up 4%. 
Q3 2016 adjusted EBITDA of $349 million includes $38.9 million incurred in connection with the cost elimination program that we discussed in the prior 3 quarters. This program is now complete. It also includes $28.6 million of integration costs relating to the acquisition of Global Workplace Solutions. 
In Q3, we continue to maintain our investment discipline around M&A as we have seen pricing increase on less stable income streams during 2016. We remain actively engaged in the market but are willing to step aside when price or terms are out of step with our underwriting criteria. 
In a similar vein, recruiting in the sales and leasing business continued at a measured pace. As noted on prior calls, we have tightened underwriting and reduced our net recruiting significantly versus the pace of the last few years. Nonetheless, we expect to add hundreds of producers, net of departures, this year while maintaining by far the highest EBITDA margins among the diversified services providers. 
Please turn to Slide 6 regarding Q3 results for our 3 regional services segment, all on local currency. Fee revenue increased 25% in EMEA and 9% in both the Americas and Asia Pacific. Without contributions from the acquisition of Global Workplace Solutions, fee revenue increased 8% in EMEA and 3% in the Americas but declined 2% in Asia Pacific. After removing the effect of foreign currency, including hedging, in both Q3 '16 and 2015, adjusted EBITDA increased 19% in EMEA and 6% in the Americas while decreasing 8% in Asia Pacific. 
Our strong performance in EMEA this quarter highlights the steps we have taken in recent years to strengthen our position. A material slowdown in transaction activity in the U.K., our largest market in the region, was more than offset by the results from 3 areas of focus: number one, significant growth in our outsourcing business; two, the strength of our business in Continental Europe, which is benefiting from an enhanced leadership team; and three, run rate operating savings from our proactive cost elimination program, which began a year ago and is now complete. 
In the U.K., overall gross revenue and fee revenue grew 20% and 12%, respectively; or 8% and 2%, excluding the acquired Global Workplace Solutions business. This growth occurred despite the slowdown in the U.K. transaction market in the wake of Brexit. 
Please turn to Slide 7 for a review of our business mix. The company's business mix has evolved significantly in recent years. Contractual fee revenue comprised 42% of total fee revenue for the company as a whole. This compares with 37% in Q3 2015 and 20% in Q3 2006. 
Please turn to Slide 8 for a review of our major global lines of business. In Q3, all percentage increases are in local currency. As Bob mentioned, occupier outsourcing exhibited a very strong growth. Organic fee revenue rose 19% without the contributions from the acquired Global Workplace Solutions accounts. Strength was exhibited around the world, with fee revenue growth rates, ex the Global Workplace Solutions acquisition, of 16% in the Americas, 21% in EMEA and 25% in Asia Pacific. 
Property sales activity was healthy by historical standards, but global sales revenue declined 7% compared with a very strong Q3 2015 when our global sales revenue rose 19%. 
In Q3 2016, EMEA saw strong growth in France, The Netherlands and Switzerland, which offset continued weakness in property sales in the U.K. in the wake of Brexit. 
Commercial mortgage services rose 24%, driven by gains from mortgage servicing rights and increased loan originations for the government-sponsored enterprises to provide financing to multifamily assets. 
Year-to-date, capital markets revenues were up 2%. In light of lower sales revenue in Q3 and the impact of Brexit discussed last quarter, we now expect our capital markets revenues to be flat to slightly up for the year. 
Leasing revenue grew 2% in Q3 compared with largely flat global market volumes and a very strong Q3 for CBRE in 2015, which saw leasing up 12% globally. Year-to-date, our leasing revenues are up 7% globally. In the Americas, robust growth in Brazil, Canada and Mexico offset flat performance in the U.S. in Q3. Year-to-date leasing revenue in the Americas has increased 9%. In Asia Pacific, leasing revenue increased 4% in Q3, led by Greater China, Japan and Singapore. Leasing in EMEA rose 3%, a turnaround from a decline in Q2. A number of countries showed strength, notably France, Ireland, Poland and Switzerland. 
Fee revenue from property management services increased by 2%. Valuation revenue was essentially unchanged for the quarter. 
Please turn to Slide 9 regarding our occupier outsourcing business, which is reported within the 3 regional service segments. This business' ongoing appeal to large space users can be seen in the 113 total outsourcing contracts, including facility management, project management and transaction management signed during Q3, including 52 expansions of client -- existing client relationships, a company record. 
In our outsourcing business, gross revenue, as determined under GAAP, depends on the contract structure while there's typically no impact on the calculation of fee revenue. As we harmonized contract structures and renewals of legacy JCI Global Workplace Solution clients, we will likely continue to experience different growth rates over time for gross and fee revenue. We believe fee revenue generally provides a more consistent view of revenue growth. 
We continue to make great inroads in the health care sector, an underpenetrated market with significant growth potential. We signed 16 total contracts in this sector in Q3, adding new clients like Brigham and Women's Hospital and Mount Sinai Health System while expanding our work for existing clients such as Johns Hopkins. 
We're also well positioned to capture integrated multiservice, multi-geography mandates. One recent example was ExxonMobil, which selected CBRE to provide integrated facilities, project and transaction management services throughout Asia Pacific and the Americas. 
CBRE's capabilities enable us to create competitive advantage for our global clients and, in turn, drive growth opportunities in our outsourcing and transaction businesses. 
Please turn to Slide 10 regarding our Global Investment Management segment. Adjusted EBITDA for this business totaled $19 million, down from a particularly strong Q3 of 2015. This decrease was driven by the timing of carried interest. Just $2 million of carried interest revenue was realized in the current quarter compared with $19 million in the prior year period. Attesting to the strong returns this business line generates for its clients, total equity commitments in Q3 rose to $2.1 billion, the highest level in 9 quarters. Total equity raised over the past 12 months increased to $7.4 billion. 
Assets under management totaled $87.9 billion, up $5 billion from a year ago in local currency. Foreign currency movement over the past year limited the increase to $1.9 billion in U.S. dollars. This reflects the fact that approximately 60% of our AUM, excluding securities, is in Europe and is generally denominated in euros and pound sterling. 
Please turn to Slide 11 regarding our Development Services segment. This business continue to perform well. Adjusted EBITDA totaled nearly $16 million for Q3 while pro forma revenue, which includes gains on real estate sales, equity earnings and noncontrolling interests, increased to $43 million. Development projects in process totaled $7.1 billion, up $400 million from Q3 2015. The new projects pipeline totaled $3.7 billion, down $300 million from a year ago as projects have converted from pipeline to in-process. When looking at our Development Services and investment segments together, as noted in the last quarter, we continue to see some uncertainty as to the timing of the realization of incentives. 
Please turn to Slide 12. Before I turn the call back to Bob, I'd like to briefly highlight our results for the first 9 months of 2016. Fee revenue increased 19%, and adjusted EBITDA rose 12%, both in local currency. Adjusted earnings per share increased 10% or 13% without the effects of currency changes, including hedging. This strong performance was on top of an exceptional growth for the first 9 months of 2015 when we achieved growth rates of 24% for adjusted EBITDA and 30% for adjusted EPS, both without the effects of currency, including hedging. 
Now please turn to Slide 13 for Bob's closing remarks.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim. CBRE has continued to produce strong results for our shareholders as we invest in our people and platform, including digital initiatives, to drive long-term growth and create superior outcomes for our clients. Commercial real estate fundam
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim. CBRE has continued to produce strong results for our shareholders as we invest in our people and platform, including digital initiatives, to drive long-term growth and create superior outcomes for our clients. Commercial real estate fundamentals remain healthy in most parts of the world, and the global economy continues to grow at a modest pace. CBRE, as the clear market leader, is well positioned to achieve strong long-term financial performance and widen our competitive advantage in the marketplace. 
We continue to expect adjusted EPS for the full year of $2.15 to $2.30, which represents solid growth of approximately 9% at the midpoint of the range on top of an exceptional performance in 2015. 
Before we close, you'll note that this morning, we announced an authorization to repurchase up to $250 million of our shares over the next 3 years. The strength of our balance sheet, considerable cash flow and resiliency of our business gives us the flexibility to return capital to our shareholders while continuing to make long-term growth-oriented investments. 
With that, operator, we'll open the line for questions.

componenttext: Tony, this is Jim. Yes, I guess I would just comment overall on the margins. Our margin for the quarter was 16.5%. Our margin year-to-date is 16.4%. The margins are only down modestly and basically back to where they were a little over a year ago. So we've given back some of the operating leverage that we picked up last year. But the margins I think have held up pretty nicely, especially after the acquisition of GWS and after the fact that sales have been down this year.
